question: Can I use the Trifield meter to test the EMF coming out of another identical Trifield meter? Or will they both explode?
answer: What makes you believe that the meter is emitting EMF energy? It's antennas within the meter case are simply responding to the measured magnetic, electric, and radio wave(microwave) energy present at the location of the meter. There is no energy present between 2 such meters to cause any explosion. I have no idea where you came up with the idea that the meters are emitting energies of themselves. The meters contain a simple 9 volt battery in them to power the meters, but this is of no consequence whatsoever.

question: does this do anything different or the same type of sanding as the work station? trying to decide if I need both or just the full work station?
answer: The "Workstation" is like a mini drill press that can also be used for free hand edging/shaping. This is ment more for straight edge work or to dig a chennel down a small board like a router, they are quite different but I guess there use can overlap just a bit. It works by picking the bit you want (for the edge shape or chennel you want) then running the wood across to get the end product. As with all these Dremel accessories (which this is no exception too,) there very plastic and meant only for very light work. I have both this and the "workstation" and was dissapointed in how weak they really are, though they do work on small projects. My #1 issue with the "Shaper/Router Table" is that when making a small chennel down the inner side of a door trim board the guide would not hold and slip thus making the chennel go off to one side, had to catch it, re-align and tighten again, ended up with pretty messy work for a pretty light job. The workstation would not have worked at all for this purpose.

question: Is this one able to be calibrated ??
answer: Calibration is easily done by simply rotating a small screw inside the battery compartment. Unlike higher priced sound level meters, this Wensn SLM's calibration screw is very sensitive; small rotation angles cause large changes to the calibration, so be careful and double-check your adjustment. Obviously you will need either a precision calibrator or, less reliably, an already calibrated SLM to compare sound levels to. I've checked two new Wensn SLMs when first purchased and they both were within the advertised calibration range, at least for the 1000 Hz frequency that most calibrators generate. These are less accurate though and not linear enough at the extremes of their advertised frequency range.

question: what size fittings? 3/8 or 1/4?
answer: Yea, that makes a lot more sense than paying for a 3/8 inch hose and then restricting it to just 1/4" at each end. But the reason that they do that is that the cheapy connectors that are so popular in the home stores are the crappy 1/4" ones. I throw those in the garbage and use the larger 3/8" connectors. My air tools, especially the rotary ones, are much happier with the larger connectors. In fact, the documentation with some of them require at least a 3/8" air flow path to achieve the designed performance. Using 1/4" fittings would have crippled those tools. That said, this hose should be fine for low air consumption devices like nailers, etc... Just beware...

question: Is this unit approved for use in and RV?
answer: You posed an interesting question so I thought I would do some research on the internet. According to the user documentation for this model (the documentation can be found under the "Download" tab on the http://www.firstalert.com/component/flexicontent/45-battery/288-battery-operated-carbon-monoxide-alarm web page), the CO detector can be installed "In Mobile Homes: Install CO Alarms on inside walls ONLY. Uninsulated outside walls and roofs of mobile homes often transfer heat and cold from outdoors. The Alarm should be located at least 6 inches (152 mm) from all exterior walls and at least 12 inches (305 mm) from supply or return vents." (I realize a mobile home is not an RV but the above information should be useful in determining if there is a place available given the above requirements.) The document also lists where co alarms should not be installed: "DO NOT LOCATE THIS CO ALARM: * In garages, kitchens, furnace rooms, or in any extremely dusty, dirty or greasy areas. * Closer than 20 feet (6 meters) from a furnace or other fuel burning heat source, or fuel burning appliances like a water heater. * Within 5 feet (1.5 meters) of any cooking appliance. * In extremely humid areas. This alarm should be at least 10 feet (3 meters) from a bath or shower, sauna, humidifier, vaporizer, dishwasher, laundry room, utility room or other source of high humidity. * In areas where temperature is colder than 40 F (4.4 C) or hotter than 100 F (37.8 C). These areas include unconditioned crawl spaces, unfinished attics, uninsulated or poorly insulated ceilings, porches, and garages. * In turbulent air, like near ceiling fans, heat vents, air conditioners, fresh air returns, or open windows. Blowing air may prevent CO from reaching the sensors. * Outside the Mobile Home. * In direct sunlight." I hope this helps.

question: EnergyStar compliant?

question: Can I line/seal a wooden barrel with this--for a standing water feature?
answer: Hi Maureen. I just read the instructions on the can and it does not specifically say it is for underwater sealing. It does say for directing flow, sealing cracks, etc. I used it On my stream feature and some of it is definitely underwater. I have not had a leak since using it and am pleased with the product. It takes 8 hours to fully cure. In my opinion it would seal a barrel, however, I think the wood on the barrel will slowly wick the water through. Also, the material you are applying the foam to must be clean and dry. Most times when a barrel is used it has a preformed liner in it. Perhaps try a small piece of pond liner? I hope it helps. Happy ponding (or barreling in your case)

question: What's the diameter of the "nail?" I have chairs that have small holes already in the legs and I'm curious whether or not these will fall out.
answer: I just measured the "nail " part and it is a rather large .345" as measured with a very accurate electronic caliper. If the chair or table legs you are wanting to nail them into is less than about 1" diameter, you will risk splitting the leg. I know, I speak from experience. The one good thing is that with the "nail" being so large in diameter, it won't bend even in tough wood. They are also rather sturdy by comparison with other products. For thinner chair legs that need a more conventional nail that is only about 1/16th inch diameter, you might try Mintcraft FE-50320 Plastic/Felt Glides. I have also tried these. Buy extra of them though as some of them fell apart while nailing them in place, and they bend readily. One has to nail them very square with the head of the hammer, and be very gentle. They are a bit cheaply made. I had better quality with ones I bought at Home Depot or my local hardware store.

question: will this unit supply enough hot water for 2 people and 2 baths?
answer: Our experience is YES, the Stiebel Eltron Tempra 24 Plus will supply enough hot water to draw baths (or showers) for two people simultaneously. The unit is rated as a "whole house" tankless water heater for a two bedroom house or condo, but two simultaneously open hot water taps basically reaches the production capacity of the unit (about the same as a 40-50 gallon conventional tank water heater). There are many variables...the efficiency/production of the unit depends upon the temperature (coldness) of the incoming supply. If your tap water is at 35-40F, then the unit will not produce as much hot water flow as it would, if your incoming tap water supply was at 50F, as it takes the two little "boilers" inside the unit longer to heat very cold tap water to the set temperature and the "flow"/volume of hot water is "reduced" accordingly. The temperature that you set the unit at is also a factor...if the unit is set "low" at say 105F then the effect will be that you will seem to not have as much hot water, because you will not be mixing in very much cold water at your bath spigot or your shower head. We set our unit at 126F, because our dishwasher recommends an incoming hot water supply of 125F, and this works out well for us. We are just two people in a two bedroom house and this unit is sized perfectly for us and always delivers and supplies our hot water demands, plus the hot water flow is "endless", as the unit will continuously heat water to the set temperature as it flows through it...one can wash load after load of clothes in hot water, or a football team could take showers one after another and there would always be hot water. Plus, the unit very, very efficiently uses electricity to heat water, much more efficiently than a conventional tank-type electric water heater.

question: Do I really need the Bridge device or can I configure using my own router and NAT? Thanks
answer: You must have the Bridge to configure the lock. For security reasons, the Bridge and lock communicate on an encrypted protocol. If you elect to not use the Bridge you will simply not be able to change the PIN or access any advanced functions. Even without the Bridge, the lock is a high-quality electronic lock and is well worth the money.

question: Glenn wants to know if it really worth it. Or should I make my own
answer: -> You will need to either carry or purify one gallon per person per day (Red Cross, CDC, FEMA)<- I have looked at this kit in detail, and I think it makes a fair car kit or a one day bag, but for a true 72 hour kit you will need more water and tarp than this. I did not buy this kit, so I can't comment on quality, but the list of items is a good start. I especially like the addition of the contagion masks. These are cheap and you should have one a day for each person in your family, for as long as you can. The work gloves are a nice addition, showing that the designers have had enough bushcraft blisters to give this kit some consideration. Having said that: Since this product has (a little) water and some work gloves and bushcraft items, I assume it is intended to be used outside your home environment ("bug out"). First, a word about bags themselves: IMHO this bag is not optimized for an offsite recovery attempt. If you are going to be away from home, it will most likely be in a FEMA camp of other storm shelter; your family will be best served by preparing a backpack for each person that can carry one. Bags must only be DRAB colors, and should NOT say emergency or supplies anywhere on them. A bright red bag that says "supplies" makes your loved one a target. Next, what to put in your drab backpack: Many good bug-out packing lists (Red Cross, NOAA, CDC, FEMA, various survival blogs) are available on line. No single bag can hold all your family will need for three days in a shelter. Make a pack for everyone that looks like a regular, lightly worn, everyday backpack. I would suggest that the smaller items like toilet paper, extra plastic baggies and very light things are carried by the children. Toilet paper is nearly weightless and has colossal bartering value. A word about redundant supplies; put lots of TP, sporks, zip strips, twist ties, toothbrush, earplugs, insect stick, chapstick, sunscreen, band aids, and the like in each bag, in case one is stolen or lost. Adults should generally carry heavier (most of the water) items, and SOS, Millennium, or equivalent food bars. Each bag should have tethered on the outside a very loud whistle, as you might become separated in crowds of evacuees. A crank flashlight, ideally with a USB port, is essential in each bag. I'll leave the rest of the items to your review of online bug-out bag lists. There are hundreds. Pack smart and light. Weight is so important: Take the bags on a yearly hike. Listen for rattling, feel the straps. Can you reach the whistle? Unpack and repack twice a year. Any bag that is too heavy to hold over one's head walking for a full minute is a liability to the wearer. Don't go overboard with big knives and spears and things like that. You won't be walking into the public storm shelter carrying a macho battle axe / flamethrower combo. You will need a small multi tool worn on the belt of each adult. Don't stand out. And for heaven's sake enough with the camo. On the opposite side of the coin: If you plan to recover in place or "bug in", you won't be wearing this bag around the house anyway, so it would not be useful. If you are bugging in, the bag is not needed, better to store two (the more the better) weeks of water, one gallon per person per day, and two weeks of dry food as a starting point. The list of bug in materials is extensive. Think power outage, thirsty neighbors. If you plan to ignore an evacuation order, you'll need to be able to black out the windows, and stay indoors for a few weeks at least. Think Katrina. Do yourself a favor, don't ignore evac orders. Have a plan to bug in, and a plan to bug out. The gear is different, but the water and food will be the same. Let's hope we won't need these, and at the same time pack like we know we will.

question: I need a product to repair a crack/leak in a very large ceramic pot that is used as a waterfall base. Will this product work for that usage?

I would definitely give it a shot. I would recommend keeping pressure on it after you glue it for at least five minutes and then letting it dry for at least 24 hours before you try it. I actually waited 48 hours, but I had such bad luck with other products before, that I allowed extra time, though I think it would have worked. Also - after I put the epoxy inside the area that broke off, I also sealed it on the outside with the epoxy, to just make sure. It is somewhat clear, so I would imaging if you are running water, you wouldn't see that extra layer of epoxy on the outside.

question: how to install when there are 3 on the same circuit?
answer: First, read the excellent directions that come with the unit. I am not an electrician but I have done extensive electrical work in my home, including wiring a finished basement. If your other three outlets are "upstream" from the X7599-W, eg are wired on the LINE (hot) side of the X7599-W, connect the incoming LINE wires to the LINE terminals of the X7599-W. Do not remove the yellow tape over the LOAD terminals. The other three outlets will not be protected by the X7599-W in this case. If the other three outlets are "downstream", eg on the LOAD side of the X7599-W, connect the incoming hot LINE wires to the LINE terminals of the X7599-W and the LOAD wires (going to the other three outlets) to the LOAD terminals (after removing the yellow tape) of the X7599-W. The other three outlets are protected by the X7599-W in this case.

question: Need to repair rotted wood out of doors (fascia) & to fill nail holes on aluminum siding. What is better this or 3M Bondo Home Solutions Wood Filler?
answer: repair of the rotted wood is best first treated with one of two types of rot repair liquids. first is an liquid expoxy and the second is a water based solution that rehardens the wood. Both are available on Amazon at a good price. the water based system is much easier to apply and to clean up. the expoxy is stronger and better at treating really badly rotted wood. after treating the wood, then the bondo can be used to fill any defects and the nail holes in the siding. note there are two different bondo products, one for just wood and the second for all purpose. both work well for filling holes. it is important to understand that the wood rot needs to be "hardened" before filling the defects or the bondo will not stick to the wood. good luck!

question: What does the beeping noise mean? When I press the on button it makes a beeping noise and all the lights flash on and off, It never stops.

Usually you would place the scanner on the wall at a place where you know there is no stud and then start moving it towards where you believe there should be a stud. It should not be beeping and flashing all the time. It should only do this when it approaches and then finds a stud. If you can't make it work, it may simply be a bad unit. question: Is there a charger for this flashlight that charges all 4 batteries in the unit at the same time? If so, can you provide a link to it?
answer: 18650 (A or B) aren't charged in the device. They are high power batteries that should be charged in a stand-alone charger that "conditions and maintains" the battery to prevent premature failure and ensure a proper load. If not charged correctly, these batteries can fail DRAMATICALLY. I use the Xtar VP1 chargers because they bring the battery down to an optimum level before charging them all the way up to the full 4.2 volts. The charger also maintains a steady charge rate and has a digital display of the voltage. Great little charger that protects these very expensive batteries. There are, of course, several other brands/models that also charge and maintain 18650 batteries. The Xtar is just my favorite. I have two Sky Ray Kings and tons of other CR123 and 18650 battery operated lights. Sort of a hobby/addiction/money hole! :)

question: can this product be "wiped" on?
answer: "Wiped on" is the only way I use Varathane now. I take a paper towel, dab it into the can, and carefully rub it onto the wood. I just did this with some repurposed cigar boxes the other night - came out beautiful. The finish seams to be a little more satiny than when you brush on the Varathane - the first project I did, I brushed on many coats and the pieces were a bit shiny. I prefer the wiped finish, it looks great on both of the Cigar Box Guitars that I've built and, as I mentioned, the two cigar boxes I just redid. You want to avoid putting on very thick layers, as well as leaving any gobs or lines of the finish, just like with anything else you're putting on wood. General rule of thumb with this stuff - if it looks white or creamy on the wood, it's too thick. Be careful sanding between layers, since the wiped on finish, for me, is often thinner than brushed on finish. Side note - The guitars only have Varathane on the neck. The wood for the necks came from an old dining room table, it's heavy and dense. The wood was stripped of finish, painted with a variety of colors and chemicals to reach a certain patina, and then I wiped on the Varathane. Came out beautiful, and the finish is holding up really well.

Ask your mail carrier where they want it and how tall. Overall the length of that post, measuring from the top of the ball finial to the bottom edge of the post is 71". This is also a Postmaster Approved Mailbox. As for the address numbers, after you place your order you may e-mail us with the numbers you need. If we don't hear from you within 24 hours we will call you to find out what you need. Your mailbox plaque will never be sent without confirmation of the numbers you need. Be sure to specify if you want 100% brass numbers attached, or reflective decals attached that make it easier to see your mailbox at night. Only Get My Mailbox & More! question: Anyone else have an issue with the switch's light pulsating slightly when off, and the light being controlled (CFL) also dimly flashing in unison?
answer: I have illuminated switches (maybe these) and the issue lies in the fact the illumination feature relies on a completed circuit and a small current to illuminate the switch. If no bulb is present in the connected socket, the switch does not illuminate. If a incandescent bulb is installed, the switch illuminates, and the small electric current is not visible in the light bulb. If an LED bulb is installed, the switch illuminates or pulses, and the LED bulb flashes due to the small current (charging the capacitor inside the bulb I assume).

question: Can a BRK Model 92120B smoke detector directly plug in and replace an old BRK Model 4120B smoke detector (without an adapter)
answer: I found an interconnect chart from BRK brands that says that the 9120B is compatible with the 4120B. That chart can be found here: http://www.brkelectronics.com/BRK%20images/BRK%20Interconnect%20Chart-Hardwired%20Smokes,%20CO's%20&%20Heat%20Alarms.pdf It did not mention anything about requiring an adapter. It just says it's compatible. So that means that there is no guarantee the mount will be the same or that he pigtail adapter will be the same, although it could be. It simply means that the 9120B and the 4120B can communicate with each other in an interlinked fashion (one alarm sets off all alarms). I would expect that at most, you would need to change the mount and connect up the new pigtail adapter. Even if it's not "plug and play" you should be able to get it to work for you.

question: I am trying to fill a 1/4 in gap between plywood sheets. Would it provide support (or crumble) if I put a screw thru?.
answer: It is similar to a semi-soft dense foam when dry. Not crumbly. More like firm rubbery spongy. It does not fully "harden" like some foams do (probably a built-in safety feature to keep it from over-expanding and busting things like some of the original "expanding foams" did). Does not have any real stand-alone structural strength any more than styrofoam let's say, but will fill gaps nicely. If you were using it "sandwiched" between two sheets of plywood it would add some structural strength I should think. You may have to trim it around the edges with a razer blade or something similar after it expands and drys. Keep in mind that IT DOES !EXPAND! question: 92599 liner instructions say to hang horizontally. I have always hung wallpaper vertically. Why ?

question: What am I doing wrong? This light is almost usless in semi light conditions ...trying to look say into a dark place...like repairing a appliance or
answer: I am very impressed with my light. I only use the rechargeable battery as I get the brightest results. There are also 5 light settings which can be chosen by turning the light on and "double clicking" the on/off button 1. Brightest 2. Mid brightness 3. Dimmest setting 4. Flash 5. SOS. you may have it on the wrong setting. Also, the lense slides in and out. Compressed would be a very wide light, making it dimmer. Sliding the lense out (grand the head and tail ends and pull) gives a more direct and brighter beam of light. Also. Your battery or batteries may be close to dead. Try replacing the batteries or recharging the battery. Again I prefer the rechargeable. Lastly. You may not be charging your battery fully. It must remain on the charger until full. When you place the battery in the charger the indicator light will light up red. When full it will change to green. And depending when the last time the battery was charged will take a long time. I work overnights at work once a month so I charge it before my overnights start. When the week is over I don't charge it till the next month. I have had it take 24 hours to fully charge. But that's my doing. I'm sure if you charged it once a week or so it probably won't take as long. I hope this helps. I spent $40 on this light and it's the best $40 I ever spent. I dropped the light in a pond and dropped it from 150ft+ in the air and it still works as new. Very tough and reliable light. Like I said. Hope this helps

question: If you mark the spot for your hole with a pencil dot, how do you position the guide so that you will be drilling in that exact spot? Thank you.
answer: I would thread your chosen bit (the bit has not been chucked up yet) through the appropriate hole while lifting the drill guide a bit so you can see the tip of your bit and your pencil mark. Then press the bit tip into your pencil mark so the bit doesn't change positions when you ease the drill guide down on the wood. Now clamp the drill guide in place so it can't move, while continuing to hold it in place with your free hand. Now chuck the bit and drill your hole, knowing that you will drill through your pencil mark.

question: problem with soap scum? Any advice?
answer: It is a lot of work to remove old hard water/soap scum residue. It is almost impervious to hot water, and most chemicals (except very harsh acids) because, it's like plastic once its layered on for a long time. One suggestion I got that really worked on ceramic wall tile (I was cleaning up a dirty rental apt), which not involve burning my lungs with acid vapor in a confined shower space, was to simply physically remove the scum with a razor blade paint scraper. It's the ones people use to remove stickers from windows, etc. You can buy them at hardware stores or dollar stores. (Always be careful and remember where your fingers are while working with a razor!). Firmly and steadily shave/scrape down then across the surface of the dry tiles and you will see many layers of soap scum residue come cascading off (like a powder). You can rinse it all down the drain if you like. Then use the steamer to finish off the remaining residue, then maybe use windex to remove all traces of residue. Voila! The next scheduled cleaning with the steamer should be much faster and easier . Tip: After the tile is all squeeky clean and looks as new, try rubbing it with some Turtle Wax to inhibit build-up till the next regular cleaning.

question: I need to demolish a piece of solid concrete about 3" deep by 6" wide by 40" long. Will this work, or should I look at a SDS-Max drill?
answer: Whether target concrete is raised as a step or slab excavation, drilling and chiseling will get the job done. My following note addresses slab excavation. By drilling an outline of area to be removed - say 1" to 2" apart using a smallish ( I used 1/2" SDS ) drill bit - your concrete will crumble when hammered with a chisel bit - I used 3/4" wide Viper chisel ). Removal of about .5 sq.foot took maybe 1/2 hr. You are removing about 3 times as much material but I'm sure you will excavate at a faster rate as you learn how your tool operates. Apart from perforating the concrete ( avoids cracks outside removal zone ), a sledge hammer helps greatly when broken concrete lumps lock up on each other. Good Luck !

question: The tube (2 x 3) fastens to the rail. Are the threaded holes already there to fasten the 2 parts together?

question: is a merv rating of 8 better than an 11
answer: Yes and No.The higher the Merv rating, the more strain you will put on your furnace/blower. The more denser (Higher Merv rating) the filter, the more your blower motor will have to work. Of course, you will pull out more particles/dust/pollen etc out of the air, with a higher Merv rating. I have a variable speed blower motor/fan, so my Hvac technician can adjust my blower/fan speed. For my house, approx. 1600 sq ft, I found the Filtrate 1000 (Approx Merv rating of 11) to be ideal, with my two cats. I also buy charcoal pre filters here on Amazon and use them with my filter. They also tend to pick up a lot of stuff out of the air. I then vacume both the filter and pre filter (with a Hepa vacume cleaner) at least twice a month. I then change my furnace filter every 4 to 6 weeks-even though the filters would be good for at least 90 days. This may be considered excessive but my Hvac tech states my coils are always clean and the house is cool/warm when I want it. Next time your Hvac tech is at your house and servicing your system, ask him/her what they recommend.

question: I want to measure the sound produced from skateboards on ramps
answer: This device is perfect for this application. However, keep in mind as always you are measuring ALL sounds in the area of the device. That is , if for example your ramps are outside and near traffic you will be measuring those sounds as well as any talking, shouting or music. These are sensitive and 'relatively' accurate - give the device a few seconds to 'settle down' / stabilize after turning it on. Expect wide fluctuations in your readings consistent with the actual sound levels the device is detecting. I've seen reviewers of various devices declare the devices as inaccurate because the readings were erratic when in fact the devices are merely 'reporting' exactly what they are 'hearing'... In a very quiet indoor setting I have seen this device show minor fluctuations from the loud ticking of a clock or traffic outside on a residential street 100-200 yards away. I use my device in a controlled - relatively sound proof music studio where its sensitivity and relative accuracy make it a perfect device for my application. Good Luck!!!

question: Can a dimmer switch be used to control the speed of this fan?
answer: No, a simple dimmer switch cannot be used and will burn out the motor. Simple dimmers reduce the voltage; this model uses an AC motor. That means that the running speed of the motor depends on the line frequency (60 Hz in the USA). If you reduce the voltage, the speed will not decrease because the line frequency is still 60 Hz; the wall dimmer has no effect on frequency. What will happen is that the motor will "try" to continue to run a the same rpm (about 850 for this model), and will draw more current to make up for the reduced voltage from the dimmer. Increased current will cause the motor to overheat and burn out. If you want a variable speed fan, you need one with a DC motor. Panasonic has several, you would have to look at them - but I am not sure Panasonic offers a DC version at this high flow rating. Sorry this may not be what you want to hear, but that's the deal.

question: I have a well does this work for well water.. country water?
answer: Hi Mary, personally I am on city water and use my filter for final polishing and not primary filtering. I would suggest you have your well water analyzed then contact Aquasana's technical support and forward them your lab results and let them tell you if their filter system is capable of purifying your water to potable standards. Please be absolutely aware of chemical toxins and biological pathogens that your lab will be able to identify. On a final note depending on you geographical location, we need to also be concerned about radiological contamination. To some extent there is a filter that is capable of addressing that problem too. question: Can I plug an extension cord into this control to operate 2 utility pumps or this control limits to one pump operation only?
answer: Answer is "Maybe" You have to look at the pumps' specs and add their amp draws. If one pump says, let's say 4.5 A, and the other 5.5, then the collective draw is 10. Glentronics switch allows for up to 12 Amps, so you would be OK there. Most average pumps, even two at a time, will probably draw under 12 amps, so you may be OK. Check the pumps' specs carefully though. But, if you ask Glentronics directly, they may say "no". The switch was UL tested to operate with one pump only, I'm sure. Running two pumps, while technically may be OK, will probably void the switch warranty and give the insurance company a reason to deny your claim. For the installation to be proper, the permanently installed pump should be connected to a dedicated breaker and be GFCI-protected, either by the breaker or by GFCI receptacle that the switch/pump plug into, and it should be just one pump. To sum up. If you plug an extension cord into the switch, will the world end? Probably not. But it is jury rigging at best. Besides, most extension cords are not meant to be installed in wet locations, and none are meant to replace permanent wiring.

question: The product shows a three wire load installation (red, black, blue,) My base board heater only has red and black wires. How would I wire this?
answer: This post might help: http://jmbldwn.com/post/13265831545/got-my-nest-thermostat-working Basically, you break the circuit going to your heater on the red wire and insert the relay in between. The red wire on the relay goes to the heater. The blue wire goes to the line (source) side. The black wire connects to the other line (black). Since 220v circuits are symmetric, you could break the circuit on the black, but this way black connects to black and red connects to red. The only color that doesn't connect to its own is blue, which connects to the line side red. If you get it backwards, you'll know because you won't be getting 24v out of the relay that is supposed to power your Nest. The relay has a small transformer inside that converts 240v to 24v, and it needs the high voltage to be on the blue and black wires. Good luck. Of course, if you're not sure, get a licensed electrician!

question: Will this work on a Yamaha Rhino, all bolts are Metric, so I am assuming the safety torx is metric or will SAE work ?
answer: TORX is neither Metric or Sae in that each bit designation starts with a T followed by the size. Examples include T30, T27, T25, etc. They come in standard TORX sizes without the center hole or security TORX with the center hole. If you don't need these elongated versions, Craftsman makes just the short bit set that also includes a bunch of other security bit types. I bought my set years ago. It includes 32 different type bits pushed into a red rubber holder. The size is 2 1/2" x 1 3/8" x 1 7/8" tall with the bits installed in the rubber holder. I highly recommend it for keeping them all together in a small space. Unless you need the long ones, stick with my suggestion or find something other than the one brand that I evaluated as totally defective. From here your on your own in that I have not had time to order from any other supplier. Just too many projects going on at once lately. Good Luck and Happy Hunting.

question: How do I program this timer? What does it mean to push down the joint slices? What are they? Where do I find them? Thanks.
answer: The little black levers (first row) around the entire time dial get pushed down for the time you want the timer to be "on". I usually set the time to the current time (turn the dial) and then push down the black "levers" starting with one or two before the current time (this allows the unit to start up once it is plugged in). It's difficult to push just one lever down at a time so push a few down and then pull back those you don't want. Hope that helps

question: So how is the volt meter wired to a 2-pole circuit? These tiny 18g wires will handle 40A?
answer: I soldered a short piece of #14 solid wire to the two voltage leads and covered with heat shrink tubing. Then I put these leads under the lugs of my sub-panel(feed from my generator) to read the incoming voltage from the generator. The meter comes with a coil which is placed around the circuit wire, this generates a very small current in the coil which the meter converts to the actual amperage, therefore the coil wire is carrying very little current. I hope this helps.

question: What is the operating wattage
answer: In all honesty I do not know what the wattage is. I know that it comes on at about 36 to 38 degrees and does not get hot, but it does have just the smallest amount of heat to keep plastic, PVC, or copper water pipes from freezing. All it does it keep the pipes above freezing. that's the reason you have to cover the tape with foam wraping, to hold the small amount of resistance heat next to the pipes and not let too much free air get to the tapes. I leave mine on all winter and our electric bill has not risen at all and we've had temperatures in the low teens. Depending on where your from, that many not be much but I really don't care as I don't have to spend the money to dig up frozen pipes to fix them.

question: What do you mean "bypass" ??? When talking about humidifiers???
answer: By Pass humidifiers is when the water passes over an element, older drum type humidifiers had a trough which held water. When operating a drum with a sponge like material would pass through the trough, picking up water which would infiltrate the hot air of the was producing, thus increasing the house humidity. Problem was, many times water in trough would build up with minerals, the sponge like material would clog not picking up water, and I heard that the trough water would stagnate, possibility causing health problems. With the pass trough system, the element that delivers water to the air requires cleaning at the beginning of the heating season, that's it, makes life easy. Hope this help, suggest if you need further assistance to check out the Honeywell web site or a local heating contractor, again if you are not handy, do not attempt to install this yourself.

question: Measurments / dimentions of the unit and minimum width of ladder leg suitable for.
answer: The measurements are: 5 & 1/2 inches high by 2 & 1/4 inches wide. Of course that does not account for the legs. That is the actual measurement of just the unit that holds the extendable legs. I personally installed this unit on a smaller non-commercial 16' extension ladder where the legs are only 2 & 3/4 inches wide. At minimum, you should be able to install it on ANY ladder that isn't narrower than the unit, so it should fit on any ladder that is at least 2 & 1/4 inches wide. Keeping in mind that if there is a lip or ridge on either side of the ladder leg (like what you find on an extension ladder), you will want to make sure that the measurement is between the ridges of the ladder leg. Realistically, the ladder would have to be very small for the Louisville ladder extender not to fit. If you are using it on a ladder that doesn't have a ridge or lip on the legs, I don't see why the unit couldn't extend slightly beyond the sides of the ladder legs since the unit's bolt holes are closer together than 2 & 1/4 inches

question: What does the slim design add to the functionality of the bulb?
answer: Function isn't really how one should look at the slim design. Light Emitting Diodes tend to be rather directional in how they emit light. In a typical household current LED bulb the LEDs point away from the socket. Depending on the application this is fine. However, for lamps such as a table lamp, this directionality leaves the light emitting up, but leaves the table the lamp is placed on poorly illuminated. The ring you see on these lamps contains a loop of LEDs. Since the LEDs now face outward from the bulb, instead of upward, they broadcast the light much more like a traditional tungsten element bulb. Behind a translucent lamp shade these bulbs look like a regular frosted bulb. The biggest difference you'll find between these LED bulbs and incandescent ones when illuminated will be heat production.

question: If you put a heavy weight on it, let's say 200 pounds, and you push it, IS THE HANDLE STRONG ENOUGH NOT TO BREAK?
answer: Yes, the handle is strong enough to not break, at least, in my experience with the Flatform. HOWEVER, you also need to consider the terrain that you're pushing on. If it's gravel or grass or any surface that isn't hard and flat, then you could break the handle because you're exerting much more force to overcome the terrain. Even the threshold of a door can be a problem at times. I've found that pulling through the door is usually better than pushing through, because of the way that the exerted force is transferred through the mass that you're moving (pulling is more efficient and doesn't compromise the handle's mechanism). I've found that lifting the front with my toe is faster and easier than fighting with the cart. Make no mistake: This is NOT a tool for heavy-duty tasks; it is for light-but-unwieldy to moderate weights, in ideal conditions, where storage space for a regular cart isn't practical (like an office). I've learned these things the hard way and yes, my handle is a little wobbly, but I will buy another one! (Hopefully, they'll put a BRAKE on the next model.)

question: What is the intended use for this water heater?
answer: This water heater has several possible uses. In my own house, I installed it under the kitchen sink (in series with house hot water heater) to provide nearly instant hot water in the kitchen. Before installation, hot water arrived in about 1.5 minutes, now it arrives in 5 sec. Another use for this heater would be in a small apt or garage where there is only a sink and no shower. This small water heater does a nice job of providing hot water in such a situation. I chose the 4.5 gallon size thinking it would actually fit in the cabinet under the kitchen sink, but there was not enough space. So, I installed it on a small platform below the floor joists in the crawl space. I plumbed it so that I could still run on just the house hot water heater if needed. So far, no problems (6 months).

question: installation check list
answer: You will need some basic familiarity with plumbing and electricity - nothing complicated; shutting off the breaker for the water heater and cutting and gluing some pvc pipe for the condensation drain. The instructions are step-by-step and quite thorough. You will need: a hand truck or dolly to move the heater, it's heavy. A large adjustable wrench and new water heater hose connectors, a phillips screw driver, teflon pipe tape, some 1/2" PVC (length will depend on where you put the drain), you will need at least a 1/2" PVC T-fitting and pvc glue. I didn't have a drain nearby, so I ran my pipe under the house and out through the exterior block wall which was quite a bit of work. The instructions can be downloaded here: http://products.geappliances.com/MarketingObjectRetrieval/Dispatcher?RequestType=PDF&Name=49-50292-1.pdf

question: fit ryobi
answer: First off let me say I believe any base can be made to fit any router. It depends on your skill and having a simple tool to align the center of the base with the router collet. The tool often comes with a set of guides that every router user should have anyway. The procedure is straightforward: Setup the base on the router using the alignment tool and accurately mark the locations of the screw holes for the mounting screws. Drill and counterbore the base. Remove the base, alignment tool, and the old base. Mount the new base and you're ready to go. The cautions lie mainly with the accuracy of the screw hole locations. If they are not dead on, you will have problems with everything you do in terms of accuracy and convenience. Good luck.

question: Have a 12V lighted switch powering a relay controlling the WH on my RV. Can I use this as timer for the heater? Switch has device, + and ground wires.
answer: If I understand your question there are a couple of ways to do this. Since the timer is going to power the relay there will be no issue with amperage draw. The relay doesn't draw appreciable current, it's just a relay. One way to proceed is to install the timer "upstream" of the lighted switch. In this approach you wire the timer into your 12 volt system (remember a fuse or breaker and check the ampacity of the wire) your timer becomes the source of power to the lighted switch and in turn the relay. Of course the heavy load that your relay controls remains wired as it always has been. Should you wish to shut down the heater for a long time you can simply turn off the lighted switch and ignore the timer. A second approach would be to remove the lighted switch entirely and simply use the timer as the power source for your relay. Again just for the switching, not for the load. These timers can be programed but they also have a manual function so you can over ride the programming and turn your heater on manually should you choose.

question: ceramic tile: will this tool cut ceramic tile?
answer: The blade seems to be a wave-set hacksaw type edge, presumably with teeth made of high carbon or "high speed" steel. I've learned through costly experience that even if the teeth are the much harder material called tungsten carbide (highly unlikely here), they will be destroyed almost instantly by even the softer grades of ceramic tile.The best reliable way to saw ceramic tile is with a diamond grit blade or bur. Diamond blades are readily available at about $30 to fit common inexpensive 4-1/2 inch high speed angle grinders. Small diamond-grit burs to fit Dremel or RotoZip type tools are far less expensive and allow finer control of the cut but they cut much slower and don't last nearly as long. Whatever you do, be SURE to protect your lungs from the tile dust to minimize chances of acquiring the deadly disease called silicosis.

question: I purchased two fans can i run them off one wall controller?
answer: The short answer is no. You may be able to get it to work but I'd advise against it. Here's the long answer: I bought two of these fans during construction of our new house and had hoped to run them both off one controller. The electrician who wired the house connected both fans to a "universal" fan controller, the kind that fits inside the wall box like a light switch. One fan would work pretty well but the other fan would only jerk as though it were trying to start but couldn't. The electrician then tried a similar controller that was supposed to control multiple fans. They both worked better but made noise. About this time I dug up the instructions for both the fans and the controllers. The fan instructions specifically say "To reduce the risk of fire or electric shock, do not use this fan with any solid state fan speed control device, or variable speed control". The controller's instructions said "CAUTION: To avoid overheating and possible damage to other equipment, do not use to control receptacles, fluorescent lighting fixtures, or transformer-supplied appliances". We then tried running both fans with one of the supplied transformer type speed controls and that didn't really work either. We finally decided that we don't really mind the "vintage" appearance of the supplied controllers. In fact my wife actually likes the way they look. Because they stand out from the wall we mounted them above the switches controlling those circuits (on/off) so they're just above shoulder height and we're less likely to bump into them as we walk down the hall. The fans are great. We still love them and would buy them again. We'd just skip the headache of trying to avoid using the supplied controllers.

question: Any recomendations on if you should use conduit if wiring multiple cables from same start to end location?
answer: I ran this wire both on the exterior and the interior without any issues. The only reason I can think of would be if you want to make the installation a little more attractive. If that isn't the motivation for your question, I see no functional reason to do so. I would suggest that you purchase wire staples large enough to accommodate all the cables you're running in parallel so as to keep them organized. You didn't say if you intended to run it outside where it would be exposed to weather, however this cable is weatherproof as well. Running it inside conduit would certainly increase its resistance to moisture, but it may be overkill. Assuming that you can install conduit with no issues, it certainly will "pretty up" multiple cables. Depending on the number of parallel runs you intend, it may be a bit challenging to get them all snaked through the conduit. You'll likely need to pull them all at once. I hope that helps. If not, I'll address any additional questions you may have.

question: Where does the outgoing mail go? Does the mail carrier see it easily?
answer: The red "flag" on the side can be pulled out indicating there's outgoing mail. On mine, the mailman would NOT need a key. There are two doors on this box: the locked bottom compartment, and the unlocked hinged top door (it's the section on the pic of the box where "U.S. MAIL" is written. The postal worker opens the top unlocked door, and tosses the mail in where it falls into the locked compartment. There is a large clip visible right behind the top unlocked door panel for OUTGOING mail to be wedged under . With the red flag out (and especially if mail is being delivered) the postal worker will easily see it. Again, no one including the mail carrier, will need a key to get your outgoing mail, assuming it fits in the top compartment where the letter clip is. However, since no one will need a key to access your outgoing mail, ANYONE can get to your outgoing mail (but this is the case for most private mailboxes). My only issue with this mailbox is that it seems to attract a lot of bills, but I'm shopping around for a filter for this problem.

question: Does this dado cut a true flat bottom? or do the cuts have the "batman ears" on the corners? Thinking about box joints.
answer: Since the outside cutters are beveled, and protrude slightly above the flat raker teeth on the inside cutters by design, it's simply not possible for this set to cut "perfectly" flat dados. It's designed that way to reduce tear out on cross grain cuts....it's the same principle that many ATB ground blades use to reduce tear out. The good news is that the bat ears are reasonably small....they're small enough that you have to look close, and some people don't notice them. This is true of nearly every good stacked dado set on the market....maybe all, but I haven't looked at all of them yet! The better ones are a bit less pronounced than the Oshlun's, but they all exist to some degree. A box joint set could provide perfectly flat dados, but the width can't be varied much, and they'll produce more tear out on cross grain cuts. Illustration of the principle here - http://community.woodmagazine.com/t5/image/serverpage/image-id/3684i82462132DE5B5BFF/image-size/medium?v=mpbl-1&px=-1 This pic illustrates the size of the actual bat ears left by the Oshlun set - http://i6.photobucket.com/albums/y203/hewood/Saw%20Blades/oshlundadocut.jpg

question: Different reviews seem to like the driver, but I get the impression that power is not its strong suit. does it really have enough torque to drive screws for various home projects? Thanks.
answer: Most likely you will not be able to build a deck or wall with it. But it is perfect for light duties where there is a lot of screws and where impact driver would be overkill and manual screwdriver would kill your wrist. I was using it recently for repair of a wall switches. It wouldn't take out one of the screws holding electrical wire - the others it did manage. Good thing about this screwdriver is that it has locked spindle. In my case I just loosen the screw manually with DeWalt screwdriver (without pressing the switch) - then used it regular way. I also have put together a few Ikea furniture - it was great help. Also have drilled small holes in drywall and studs for shelves fasteners. It excels in situations where you have long screws which would take forever with manual screwdriver - like, for example, the screws holding a wall switch to the electrical box. Don't expect it to be a tool good for everything. You will still need impact driver when you will need more torque and drill for serious drilling. The gyroscoping action is something to get used to, sometimes it is annoying. But I think it is more smooth in action then variable speed trigger switch. I don't regret buying this screwdriver, use it all time - my only wish is it was cheaper (or at least DeWalt would add to the kit the DCL023 flashlight)

question: Does this fit my Dewalt DWE4011 ?
answer: I can't seem to cross reference part numbers on the DeWalt website in this case. My D28110, D28402, and D28065 all measure very close to 1.75" diameter at the neck, as does the inside diameter of my DWE46150. If your DWE4011 has a 1.75" neck between the wheel guard and gear housing, then this shroud should be compatible though I cannot guarantee it. The real issue is: 12000 rpm on a concrete accessory seems geared too high. I bought my 9000 rpm D28065 specifically for a concrete grinding project because it is geared much lower than a 4-1/2" grinder. You're going to bog down any gearing higher than 9000 rpm anyway, possibly overheating your 7 amp motor, so I figured tractor the gearing down. Since the project I bought it for, my D28065 has saved other projects. As always, air hammering the web between rotary hammer holes is the fastest way for most people to remove bulk concrete, not knowing the nature of your project. Hope this helps. Happy New Year to you and all.

question: The Romex in my wall only has the 3 traditional wires, black, white, and ground but this switch also comes with a red. What should I do?
answer: OK, there seems to be a lot of confusion here as to switch wiring. In a conventional setting, a wall switch will "break" only one side of the electric circuit (BLACK wire). The white wires are tied together, but NOT switched. Typically all the white wires are tucked in the back of the switchbox to keep them out of the way. Tie the Maxxima's GREEN wire to the ground (bare) wire that you removed from the old switch. Tie the Maxxima's WHITE wire to the WHITE wire bundle (2 wires for one switch, 3 wires for a second switch, et. cetera.) Tie the Maxxima's RED wire to one of the BLACK wires that came from the old switch. Tie the Maxxima's BLACK wire to the remaining BLACK wire. The Maxxima's Red & Black wires are the "switch". If, when you turn the circuit back on, the blue lights on the unit are ON, then you're OK. If not, REVERSE the Maxxima's Red & Black wires.

question: what kind of 18 V battery I have to use, 3.0 amp or can I use 1.5 amp??
answer: You'll get a longer run time with the 3.0 amp battery and it's still not a long time - 3 hours or less. Go to the Makita Tools website at http://makitatools.com/en-us/Modules/Tools/ToolDetails.aspx?Name=BCF201Z and click on the PDF "Instruction Manual." On page four of the manual there is a table that lists approximate run times for 14V and 18V and for 1.5 and 3.0 amps at each voltage. According to the table going from 1.5 amps to 3.0 (at 18V) essentially doubles the run time on low speed from 90 minutes to 200 minutes. So base your decision on what you need to do with the fan. I have the Makita fan and I like it, but the run times are quite short for what I use it for. I ended up also buying the Ryobi cordless fan which runs much longer - up to 10 hours on low speed.

question: do I need to purchase a battery?

Just Google it. But THIS tool is well worth the price. It's an Excellent tool. I ONLY buy Dewalt 18v tools. They work very well and the batteries hold their charge a long time and are interchangeable between my different tools. question: To replace the batteries, would I have to pull the entire unit off of the tape holding it onto the wall? Or, is there a way to replace the batteries without removing the entire base from the wall?

They make a very tight fit but are very easily removed. And be careful when you are mounting the taped strip. The tape is very, very sticky. Not repositionable at all. I tried to reposition one in our hallway and it tore the top layer of drywall off. They work like a charm though. We really like them. They light up a dark hallway for my elderly mother and I only had to use 2.

question: Instructions for programming the unit
answer: Plug the unit into an outlet. You should see the display come on in just a few seconds. Set current time, power ON time and power OFF time. (See instructions below.) Allow unit to stay plugged in for a couple hours to charge. If unit doesn't maintain the correct time or desired settings, replace batteries (located in small pull out tray) with 2 button style batteries (model number LR1130). To locate battery tray, look for a small crescent or semi-circle relief area near a back corner at the bottom of the unit. The relief is just big enough to snag with your fingernail. Apply a little pulling power to overcome the snap-in tray. It will slide right open. It can be hard to see due to the good fit around the tray. To set Time: Press and hold TIME button. Press HOUR button repeatedly until it matches the current hour (be mindful of AM/PM) Press MIN button repeatedly until it matches the current minute Release TIME button To set time to turn ON lamp: Press and hold ON button Press HOUR button repeatedly until it matches the hour you want the lamp to turn on (be mindful of AM/PM) Press MIN button repeatedly until it matches the minute you want the lamp to turn on Release ON button To set time to turn OFF lamp: Press and hold OFF button Press HOUR button repeatedly until it matches the hour you want the lamp to turn off (be mindful of AM/PM) Press MIN button repeatedly until it matches the minute you want the lamp to turn off Release OFF button

question: Is there an external power supply?
answer: Some have answered as if this was a dumb question. Its not. If your furnace or boiler does not provide a 24 volt lead you could use an external power supply to power this thermostat. question: what are the numbers to press to clear the old code ? I want to change the code but cant enter a new one until the old one is cleared
answer: From e-How: 1 Press and hold the "PROG," "6" and the "Open/Close" buttons in that order until the red light on the keypad comes on and goes off. 2 Release the buttons when the red light goes off. 3 Press the "3," "5," 7" and "PROG" buttons and the red light will blink. 4 Enter the new PIN (a minimum of three and a maximum of eight characters). 5 Press the "PROG" button to confirm the PIN. 6 Press the "Learn Code" button, which is either on the keypad housing near the antenna (if the keypad has a black antenna) or in the external receiver compartment. Enter your PIN. 7 Press the "Open/Close" button. The "Learn Code" indicator light will turn on and stay on. 8 Press the "Open/Close" button a second time. The "Learn Code" indicator light will go off. To test the system, wait about 30 seconds after the indicator light goes off, enter your PIN, and press the "Open/Close" button. The garage door should move. Read more: http://www.ehow.com/how_7835821_change-wireless-keyless-garage-keypad.html#ixzz2vPhG5HBu

question: Can you tell me if there's an accessory type plug-in speed control unit for power tools that will cut the speed, but not the power? Thanks
answer: With almost all power tools, reducing the power is the only way to reduce the speed. Most tools with variable speed triggers like drills or routers, the triggers are just variable resistors that reduce the power to the actual motor. The more you let off of the trigger, the more resistance, and the less power gets to the motor. This does the exact same thing as the trigger on a variable speed drill. One word of caution when using one of these, do not use it on tools with Laser Guides, or other "high tech" electronics. Only on bare bone basic power tools. I used this on my mitre saw with a laser guide to slow the blade speed down so I could use it as a chop saw and cut metal tubing. Well, the laser guide did not like the cut in voltage and after about 5 minutes of cutting, the laser guide electronics literally went up in smoke. Not just a little smoke, holy crap get the fire extinguisher kind of smoke. Needless to say I now have a mitre saw without a laser guide, but it worked great to cut the metal tubing!!!

question: Why would someone by regular (non-impact) deep socket sets instead of these if this is a harder material? Is it that they are much thicker?
answer: It isn't a harder material, it is actually softer. The softer material of impact sockets prevents them from shattering under the high stress that is put on them by impact wrenches. Normal sockets are harder but more brittle and more prone to breaking or shattering. Normal sockets are also thinner, allowing for use where impacts wouldn't fit

It's wrapped in foam board insulation as well as the usual in-wall cavity insulation along with triple pane windows. question: This Compressor says 4.1 CFM but will it run a nail gun that requires 4.5 ?
answer: I own several Hitachi NR83A3 framing nailers and this compressor keeps up. If one takes the cfm of air per cycle needed for that nailer and divides it into 4.1 you get 64 cycles per minute. I do not know of anyone who can keep that up. The CFM rating of 4.1 is at 90psi and not 120 which I run my framing nailers at. I bought this compressor because I wanted a compressor I could use in conjunction with another when I needed more CFM like when I texture drywall. I like the idea that this compressor is 100% duty cycle. None of these compressors I am aware of are all that good at starting in freezing weather but this compressor seems to be the best of its type. I have other compressors which are belt driven with more power and they are much better in freezing weather but they cost a lot more and are much heavier. When the compressor first starts with no air in the tank it has a check valve at the top of the compressor that allows air to bypass the tank until it has been running for a short time. This seems to help it start when it is cold and the air compressor has not run all night. Once there is some air in the tank you never hear it again until after you drain the tank. Before I bought this compressor I looked for one with a 100% duty cycle rating and found that there are very few available. While this compressor may look like most others it is my favorite hand carry compressor. After a short time I started using synthetic compressor oil because I think that helps a compressor start easier in cold weather and helps it to last longer. Before I changed the oil I spoke with someone at the company and they were great about helping me.

question: How much taller is the furniture after application?
answer: I just measured the thickness of some of these chair glides which I installed on some chairs in my family room. They add right about 1/4" to the height, probably not enough to worry about. The thing you should probably be more worried about is the thickness of the "nail" portion of the chair glide relative to the thickness of the chair or table leg you are going to nail it to. Be really careful here. If the chair or table leg is less than about 1.25" you risk splitting the wood. That happened on one or two legs of 4 chairs I nailed them to - a total of 2 out of 8 legs - and I am a very handy and experienced person. I was able to salvage the situation with wood glue and clamps. The chair legs were only about 1" in diameter, and made of oak, so they were very hard. A bit bigger diameter or a softer wood and probably no splitting would have occurred.

question: The battery holster (with 3 AA batteries in it) fit too snugly for the flashlight, and now I can't get it to come back out. It doesn't turn on. Help?
answer: It does fit snug, but I just carefully (holding the body tight) slightly shake it a little to get the battery unit sliding out. As far as it not turning on, make sure the battery unit is facing the right way with the end with the two minuses and one plus facing the end cap. (do NOT remove the end with the LEDs, only the end cap). Also try fresh batteries just to be sure. (and make sure the individual batteries are put in the holder according to the plus and minus signs) I use rechargeable batteries so I can recharge one set while having another charged set in the flashlight. Hope this helps !

question: What is the difference in a water heater that says "Not for use in a mobilehome" and a water heater that does not have this label on it?
answer: Yes. Mobile homes, also known as manufactured homes, are required to comply with the rules laid down by the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development. Mobile homes are plumbed for specific water heaters and they can be quite complicated to replace. Consequently the cost of a mobile home water heater is significantly more. Mobile home water heaters are different than regular water heaters in three main ways: Mobile home water heaters have interchangeable gas and propane orifices so that the water heater can be converted from natural gas to propane gas operation. This is the main reason for the increased cost. Mobile home water heaters have the cold water inlet connection on the side and the hot water outlet connection on top. Residential water heaters have all connections on the top of the tank. A mobile home heater comes with a securing strap kit

question: How will this light w/coiled remote switch on a Remington pump 870 tactical shotgun?
answer: It will work as long as you can find a mount that will fit both your 870 and the light. Problem is the light housing is narrow and not a standard size like other weapon lights. Behind the lenses bell the light body diameter is .900 so it's tough to find a mount to fit that. Another issue is your mount needs to stand off far enough from your weapon so the lenses of the light doesn't hit it. Another issue since most lights don't have a big lense like this one. I love the light and have one on my AR with a remote coil using a 1" Viking mount and a few layers of shrink wrap around the body so it will fit snug since the mount is for a 1" light. I'm sure there are better mounts out today then when I got mine. As long as it will clamp down below .900. But for my 870 I personally would not like it as it's overkill. For all my shotguns I use streamlight M3's with their corresponding shotgun mounts which are nice as I can slip them on and off the picatiny rail. Works very well and lower profile sitting closer to the weapon. But it's a personal choice. Hope that helps!

question: Can this switch control 2 Westinghouse 7247100 Quince ceiling fans that are wired on the same circuit?
answer: Richard, as far as the wiring goes there is no problem. What you need to be concerned about is running too much power though the switch which could cause an electrical fire. your fans are rated at 31 watts for the fan and two 40-watt light bulbs, therefore with two fans you will have a demand of 62 watts on the fan control and 160 watts on the light control. the switch is rated for 143 watts on the fan and 300 watts on the light, so you should be OK. You should still check with a local electrician that is familiar with electrical codes in your area to make sure you're safe. Good Luck!

question: Would a 3 amp inline fuse be correct? Running direct from marine 12v battery.
answer: 3 amp should work fine. If its not mission critical, you could start with a 5 and be ok. If its mission critical, i would go with 5a. These regulators do get hot if you're dropping down a lot of voltage. I use them to fun 12v leds of a 16v source and the linear regulator stay room temp. If i drop from 16 to 5v, it can get warm to the touch after long periods of time. That may blow a 3 amp fuse. I add an aluminum heatsink made for RAM on top of the coil, and it helps with the heat when you are dropping a lot of volts. For the price, it cant be beat.

question: I am still in doubt how to connect the power suply with my LED strips which are SUPERNIGHT (TM) 16.4ft 5M RGB Waterproof Flexible strip 300leds Color Changing RGB SMD5050 LED Light Strip 12V. The strip has 2 connectors with 4 wire each (BLUE, RED,...
answer: The L, N and GROUND are for the AC Input. The WHITE wire from the strip goes to the +12 V screw on the Power supply. If you hook the Blue wire to COM, the BLUE LEDs will light. If you hook the Green wire to COM, the GREEN LEDs will light and the same for the RED wire/RED LEDs. If you hook Blue, Green and Red all up to COM at the same time you will get WHITE. There should have been a small white controller box and a remote control. The strip hooks to the controller and then the +12v and COM from the power supply hook to the power connector on the controller. Then with the remote you can select the color and pattern you want the strip to use.

question: This sounds like what I need as it is stranded and high gauge but my question is: Is it flexible? Some stranded wire has a very stiff insulation.
answer: Eh, it's not the most flexible stuff I've ever used, but it's not that stiff either. It's about on par with any other low count stranded when it comes to flexibility. In general, the higher the strand count the more flexible the wire. Wire with silicon insulation is usually much more flexible as well. This stuff is nowhere near 'wet noodle' soft, but it can still be bent easily enough.

question: I understand that the early Indegogo backers already have their beddit sensors, for those of you who now have the product, how do they work?
answer: The sensor came with creases in it that don't come out, I can feel them through the sheets and they bother me while I sleep. This seems like a manufacturing/packaging defect. The iPhone app lacks much of the functionality promised during the campaign. There is no time resolved heart rate or breathing rate available to the user. I have been unable to verify that the "smart alarm" functionality works, it seems to go off at a predetermined time (i.e. exactly when you set it to go off before you go to bed). An Android app is currently non-existent despite its availability being promised by Beddit at launch time. The user must manually input (in the iPhone app) when they go to bed and then manually input when they wake up, otherwise the app will not be "measuring." The company clearly does not understand the concept of a smart sensor. Breathing rate and noise monitoring data are non-existent. The heart rate data is averaged into one number and displayed to the user after stopping measurement at wake up time, the accuracy of this number is poor (as confirmed by a traditional heart rate monitor chest strap). The nightly sleep data is made available to the user upon waking as nebulous rectangles with rounded corners seemingly indicating general times when the sensor registered the user as being wake awake or asleep during the night. The manual that shipped with the product has pages with white backgrounds and was printed with WHITE ink (I thought this must be a joke). Overall the product experience has been extremely poor, both on the hardware and on the software side. The company clearly has no pride in their work (or else they would not have shipped), no quality control and lacks people with the necessary skill sets to bring a product to market. Stay away.

question: What do you do for a pressure gauge if ther isn't one?
answer: One of the problems of the Flo-Tec is that there is only one output connection from the pump. From that connection one must "plumb" in water connections to the house plumbing, the tank input connection and usually a spigot for an inside hose connection (hose bib). Within this piping one needs to include a "tee" into which a pressure gauge can be inserted. The gauge is required to set the low pressure on adjustment and the higher pressure off adjustment for the pressure switch on the pump motor. Most of the piping I used coming out of the pump was galvanized 1/2" steel pipe and it resembled an octopus as it had to match up with existing copper pipe houseing. However it worked satisfactorily. What did bother me was the rather large size of the 1-1/4" output on the pump housing. Using a steel reducing bushing there required a lot of plastic-Teflon pipe thread sealing tape to halt the leaks caused by the rather loose fit at that joint.

question: I have high garage ceilings. would it be possible to mount this on some angle iron same manner as my garage door opener?
answer: I think so. The angle iron structure will need some cross bracing to withstand the side loading forces exerted when the cord/hose is pulled at angle. Make sure the base of your structure would be of such length/size that you would be able to bolt into a ceiling rafters at each end, this is a must. The angle must be structural material, not the perforated kind. Also, a safety lanyard should be used as well. My thoughts are not to be taken as a recommendation nor as engineering data.

question: What adapter is required for use with the PC adapter kit for PC dovetail gig.
answer: You will need the Bosch Quick Change Template Guide Adapter http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B005HPUP80/ref=oh_details_o08_s00_i00 and the Bosch RA1100 Threaded Router Template Guide Adapter http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0009H5INI/ref=oh_details_o09_s00_i00 The problem is that most places don't carry the quick change adapter, not even DIRECT from Amazon. So you have to buy it from Woodcraft online (I purchased it from Woodcraft through Amazon). I checked my local Woodcraft store and it was not available. The shipping is nearly as much as the adapter! This is a key part because without it you can't mount anything to the stock base plate for this router. You could change out the clear plastic baseplate and get a PC compliant one, but that may just open up a new set of problems. The RA1100 threaded adapter fits into the quick change adapter and it allows you to screw in any PC guide that you would need. Thankfully, this part is available directly from Amazon. I'm a PRIME member so the shipping was free on this one.

question: Approximately how many square feet can I expect to get done with a quart? Stripping paint from concrete...
answer: Pretty tricky question. I'll answer it best with another question or two. IS the concrete a "smooth" surface or is it textured? I ask this because the Soygel works best on smooth surfaces - as would most paint removers. The nooks and crannies will make the removal more difficult. I just used the Soygel on a similar job - stone. The paint coating on it was heavy and thick. I had to use a thick coat which I let really set in, then used my drill with a rotary wire head. This got off allot of the paint, but I had to do it a 2nd time to get the rest off. So, depending on the amount of coats and how thick they are, will determine the amount of coverage you can get from a quart. For my application - which I will be completing over the next week, I estimate I will need a full quart to remove an area of 54 sq. ft. Remember, I will also be using multiple wire heads on my drill to get this job done. If you decide to follow this route, use tarps on anything painted that you went to keep painted.

question: Have any of you attempted to use a photo copy of your fingerprint to get in or any other form of copying your fingerprint to see if they lock fails?
answer: Yes we have tried to fool it.and also my biometric safe..It does not open for photocopied fingerprints using even the best types of paper..The only thing it may open for is if you have a 3D printing machine that can mimic an exact silicone replica of your finger..It might open for that since it will have all the indentations and grooves of your finger..But then again why go through all that trouble when you can just go in someones backyard and kick through there window..or just take a sledge hammer and knock off the most toughest deadbolts........The Nextbolt to me is a better alternative to the standard dead bolt not only because of the little bit of increased security it gives ..but for the convenience it gives by not using keys..If you are looking for the ultimate security this should not be your top choice..You may want to consider getting a very good wireless Alarm system with motion sensor in every room using the best monitoring system tied directly to the police..Also you may want to setup internet survelance cameras with night vision around your premises so you can monitor your property on a daily basis.And probably half inch steel bars on every window with Ram resistant doors on every entry..This is how we use to live in South America......If you live in a bad area ..Do not buy the next bolt..Consider one of the other few options above that i listed..

question: Why did I have to use a separate pwr supply for the meter than the Switching Power supply that I was measuring? Would not work otherwise.
answer: I'm not sure in your particular instance what the problem was. In my case, I was hooking this up to a treadmill. As it happened at the point I was tapping into the system (power going to the motor) the amperage was too great for this device. I would have burned it out. So originally I used batteries to run it. I got tired of that solution and it occurred to me that a AC/DC switching power converter could provide the solution I was looking for. I found one on eBay and hooked it up to where the power came into the treadmill (before the motor board). I then used this as my power supply for this device and it works great. Perhaps something like that could work for you? It was only $9.98. In my case I was looking for something small I could install inside the treadmill. I was able to bolt it down in the same general area as the motor control board. I've been using this solution now for almost a year and have had no problems.

question: Why does Amazon still sell this item? It seems to be a fire hazard from reading the customer feedback.
answer: I personally use this item and can vouch for it. The only way this is a fire hazard is if people do not use it correctly. Yes there will be defective units, yes there may be accidents, but overall most fires started by these are caused by people who shouldn't even own pets. Putting a towel over this device or putting stuff around it is not smart at all and is in fact dangerous. The device itself as far as I have seen does not catch fire, and in fact does not produce enough heat TO catch on fire. I put blame on the users, not the item or manufacturer except in the case of defective units sold. Hope this was a reasonable answer. I love this product. UPDATE: Adding to my previous comment, it seems as though there was a curse on this company as a whole bunch of people got faulty devices, poor things. Mine is still working great, no shorts. Seems to me like there were assembly issues within the manufacturer building or they got some terribly made pieces to construct these with. I am only glad that mine was not one of the ill-fated defects!

question: Does this outlet support load sensing? e.g. If the switch is turned on manually, will the outlet detect the load change and appear as "on" in Vera?
answer: No this device does NOT support load sensing. It will do what you say by reporting its status back to your controller, but that is not load sensing it is status reporting. Load sensing is when the unit allows you to control whatever device you plug into it manually and still allow monitored control. ie: you can control a lamp plugged into the receptacle by using its switch but yet still control it via z-wave. This device does not support load sensing.

question: Are you able to maneuver the top arm 180 degrees or more? Secondly, does the top arm also extend to a vertical poosition? TY
answer: Hi, there are two moveable joints here...each move as hinges only...just up/down, not side to side. The top arm does Not go fully vertical...it's max angle is roughly 145 degrees with bottom arm fully vertical. The bottom arm movement is just 45 degree max. It goes fully vertical, but downwards to about 45 degrees only...it will not slope down to be fully horizontal/parralel with your desk. Now, the lamp is lightweight, so while the hinges don't swivel side to side, just move the base...it does not scratch your desk. Overall, I love this lamp with its different settings. The USB charger is very useful. Note, the top arm does fully collapse to the bottom arm and when closed like this, the lamp can be completely vertical in this closed position. I keep my lamp in basically a 90 degree position and rarely move it. I don't think the lamp is designed for constant movement, say if you were a jeweler...that would be too much wear/tear. Hope that helps. Mark in NY
