question: How are these lights attached if installed as recessed? Is there a different mounting ring? also do you have exact dimensions of these lights?
answer: You will need to cut out a 2 1/8" diameter opening. You then take the LED engine completely out of the plastic decorative housing (it just pushes out). You install the LED engine into your opening using the provided screws, connect your wires, and finally twist just the smaller 1/4" deep part of that decorative casing back onto the LED portion. You discard the top outer ring. The size of these puck lights is 2 5/8" x 1 13/16". That would be the be the size when surface mounted. When recessed, only the 1/4" portion will show. I hope that helps -- Barry, Brodwax on Amazon

question: we have a n66c what other brands will work in this gun
answer: The key to successfully using other nails is what is the head size of the nail. Generally .099 shank nails are too big (take shank and multiply by 2.5 & that number should be less than .236. So .090 and .093 is fine. You may have jamming problems with .083 and .080. So sweet spot should be shank size from .087-.093. When in doubt, owner's manual is a good resource.

question: What is the beam width of this light?
answer: For this Flash-light, I measured its strong spot-beam to be slightly over 10-degrees in diameter, and its weak flood-beam about 72-degree in diameter. In other words (and rounding), it creates a strong spot-like round beam of 2-feet in diameter from about 11-feet distance, and exhibits a weak flood-like round beam of slightly over 7 feet in diameter from 5 feet away. Just to be complete, this correspond to the T6 diving light, single white LED, twist-on, with 3 visible o-rings on the thread, and a 3.7 Li-Ion 3000mAh battery. I tested it with the cap twisted all the way in, and with a freshly charged battery. The measurement is a result of subjective observations from two subjects (my wife and myself:-)) performed at two different distances for each beam type.

question: It says I need a 5mfd/370 capacitor. My current system has a 80+5 capacitor. Will I also need an 80mfd capacitor if I replace it?
answer: No your current system has a 80+5 capacitor because that's what your current engine requires. If order this motor, you can keep your current capacitor provided you've tested it properly and it is functioning properly. There's too numbers there, 80 and 5 so long as the first number is at least 50 that requirement is met. The second number is more precise. for example you could not go with a 50+7.5 capacitor, it has to be +5. In your case of having a 80+5, 80 is well higher rated than it needs to be so your good there, and the +5 is spot on so your current capacitor will work fine (again provided your capacitor hasn't gone bad.) Hope that helps.

question: warranty
answer: I purchased 3 of these meters from Electronix, a quality vendor who focuses on customer satisfaction. I dedicated one for bench measuring voltage, one for bench measuring current, and the third for all other measuring needs. Although this meter does not appear to come with an extended warranty, at 29.99 I was not that concerned about it. I purchased 3 meters for less than it would cost for one comparable warrantied meter. I have been using them for a short while and thus far I have no complaints. I am impressed with this meter's performance and accuracy, especially considering its price. The meter has a 10 MegOhm Impedance which is NOT LOW. Anyone using this meter should remember to always make sure the leads are disconnected prior to turning the meter's range switch. I like this model of meter, and am impressed by its performance especially at such a low price. It is a bit premature for me to criticise or recommend the longevity of these meters. For now I hope my meters will last, but I am still very pleased that I decided on them.

question: Can the combs of a mandolin penetrate the weave of the glove to some extent or is the mesh tightly woven? Thanks
answer: The mesh is pretty tight. I think it would work well to protect your hands from the combs of a mandolin. When I try to poke the tip of a sharp knife straight through the weave only 1/8 inch pokes through. It could go through the glove and cut you but it wouldn't go very deep. And you would really have to work to get a knife or other sharp object at an angle that would cause it to go through the glove. Also the weave is a bit thicker, the links overlap slightly, when the glove is relaxed, giving you more protection. When the glove stretches over your hand as you are using it, it opens up to a single link but this stops most sharps just fine. Hope this helps!

question: Is the saw considered as a left hand or a right hand blade?
answer: The saw is left bladed. In your right handed the blade is to the left/inside. If a rightie, you can see the guide markings better (and cut a finger off your left hand easier) than a right bladed saw. Flip side is, usually you can not support your work piece with left hand so you may need to clamp/support what you are cutting. Depends. Being a rightie I prefer a left bladed saw, but it is a matter of taste. If you are a leftie the reverse may hold true.

question: Why do i have a salt mess near the top on the outside? It is almost like it crystalizes on the outside rim at the top?
answer: Peggy, If the salt is on the outside of the tank then the salt and water brine are overflowing the the tank. Inside the brine tank is a vertical tube that contains a valve to to stop water filling when the brine tank is full. It might have failed or the brine fill valve might be leaking allowing water to flow into the brine tank when the system isn't recharging. If I were you I'd look at the brine tank and see where the water level is. It shouldn't be higher than 1 foot from the bottom. If it is, you need a repair. My resin tank (the one in the middle) was porous and leaking water into the brine tank. I fixed it with epoxy. ps Any leak in the in/out water connections usually winds up in the brine tank. Good luck.

question: Can I use this on a single switch with no grounding?

PLS is their Pro line that's meant to be purchased from and installed/troubleshot by your electrical contractor, RPLS is Retail/Consumer/DIY line, so they do honor their warranty for the DIYer on the RPLS line. I wonder if PLS is even supposed to be available through other than a contractor. Only reason to go w/the PLS 750c is if you need 3-way or 21 program slots. question: I'm not sure what size to get. How does one choose the correct size?
answer: Grabbed the info below off the internet. What's My Size? To find out your glove size, measure (in inches) around your hand with a tape measure at the place indicated by the red line (just below the knuckles). You should use your dominant hand, the right if you are right-handed, and the left if you are left-handed. * NUMERIC SIZES: These are the same as your measurement in inches. Round up or down to the nearest size. * LETTER SIZES: Use the chart below to convert inches to letters. Round up or down to the nearest size. MEN'S SIZES size inch* cm* XS 7 18 S 7 1/2 - 8 20 M 8 1/2 - 9 23 L 9 1/2 - 10 25 XL 10 1/2 - 11 28 XXL 11 1/2 - 12 30 WOMEN'S SIZES size inch* cm* XS 6 15 S 6 1/2 16 1/2 M 7 18 M/L 7 1/2 19 L 8 20 XL 8 1/2 23 * HALF SIZES (if available): Round up to the nearest half size.

question: bought 10" oldham where r the instructions?
answer: There aren't any. The reason for this is because each table saw is different so providing instructions would be a generalization at best, unsafe at worst. Use is pretty simple - you take off your arbor bolt and remove the current saw blade. You put the dado set's blade on first taking note of the direction the saw turns. Then you add as many of the variable width chippers to create the width you want. Then add in the other dado blade on the arbor bolt, bolt it all in place and away you go. Please take note that many table saws have arbor bolt length restrictions so you may not get the full width you want. I cannot do 3/4" dado's on my table saw despite having this kit for example. Finally - please ensure you have a table saw insert specifically for dados. The alternative is to remove your insert which is unsafe. Most manufacturers sell aftermarket table inserts for a reasonable price...mine cost me $18 or so. Good luck!

question: Can anyone tell me how to turn this transformer on? No manual included and trying the on/off switch does not work? Does not come on when plugged in.
answer: There is only one way to control it - the up & down arrows. A small label next to the light sensor lists the options: 0 turns the output on, A is auto-on, that is whenever the outside light level gets low enough, everything is on. Continuing with the up arrow, it does auto with timed shutoff and each number corresponds to the number of hours before it shuts off. For example, I use a setting of 3, which turns on the lights around 8:50 PM and shuts them off 3 hours later. Pretty crude controls, but I really don't need anything more more.

question: Are all compartments lockable with a standard padlock?

question: is it energy efficient
answer: A 1,500-Watt heater running at maximum output (i.e., not cycling on-and-off after it reaches the desired room temperature) uses 1.5 kilowatts per hour. If your electric rate is 10 cents per kilowatt-hour (probably around the national average), then you're spending $0.15 per hour. Used 10 hours daily, this would cost $1.50 per day to use. If the unit is sized properly to the room, it should cycle on-and-off when it reaches the set temperature and therefore use somewhat less electricity than this estimate. Electric heat is generally the most expensive source. The BTUs from natural gas are much cheaper. Where you will save money (and help our planet) is by being able to concentrate the heat in rooms where it's needed and lower the temperature on the main home heating system. We don't use much of our upper level where the master bedroom is located, so using a local heat source allows us to keep this area around 60 degrees F except for the rooms we occupy (e.g., bedroom at night, bathroom periodically for baths and showers). If you were to run this unit at maximum output 24 hours daily, at 10 cents per kilowatt-hour it would cost $108 per month (1.5 kilowatts/hour [times] 24 hours/day [times] 30 days/month [times] $0.10/kilowatt-hour). If you're paying more than this, your electrical bill is obviously over 10 cents per kilowatt hour (remember to figure the total cost including the delivery charges and tax) like our rates in Western New York which run closer to 15 centers per kilowatt-hour (FYI: the actual rate varies with monthly usage. Higher usage levels are charged at a somewhat lower rate). Finally, realize that all 1,500-Watt heaters produce approximately the same amount of heat (i.e., that's what the "1,500-watts" represents in the specification); the differences are in how well they distribute that heat and how often they have to cycle on-and-off (cycling tends to use more energy). Oil-filled heaters tend to give a more consistent flow of heat into the room and therefore feel more comfortable by avoiding the spikes in higher and lower temperatures. A true infrared heater will heat objects in the room, not the air. These heaters tend to be more "efficient" in the sense that the effect of heating the air is quickly lost with small air drafts, while heating the 'objects' in a room retains the heat much better while producing the same type of comfort typical of an oil-filled heater. (I don't own this heater, so I can't comment on its actual performance, but I do note that the reviews seem overall positive for this model.)

question: Does the unit activate automatically in freshwater?
answer: It depends on the water. 'Fresh' water is generally not pure H2O. Even tap water has dissolved solids in it as evidenced by the calcium or 'lime' deposits seen on faucets and sinks after the water evaporates. The strobe is activated when it senses an electric current between two electrodes. When dry, it remains off because air is a poor conductor. It will probably not activate in pure rain water or distilled water, which are also not good conductors of electricity. I have activated the strobe in tap water, but it takes longer than in sea water. Most fresh water lakes and streams probably will activate the strobe, but the time to activation will vary depending on how pure the water is. The best safety practice is to test the strobe just before use by putting it in the water you encounter to see if it activates.

question: Good day, I have a question regarding ALEKO AR900 Gate Opener: 1) Can be connected to the source of 110v home while having connected my 12v batteries (configured on 24v) on the control board? 2) I have my charge controller LM118, with my solar panel...
answer: Freddy, Yes you can connect 110Volts and 24 volt battery. In this configuration the 110volt charges the battery. NOTE In this configuration the battery acts as a backup in power failure when 110 volts go out. You cannot use solar support - panel charger etc. 2. The LM 118 is the recommended Charge Controller but it seems like (1) the batteries aren't being charged properly or (2) the batteries are losing power somewhere. In the night the batteries would discharge through the solar panels but the charge controller should take care of this. What you can do is monitor the voltages over one night. Check the battery voltage at early night 6:00pm and in the morning when it does not open the gate. Then the second night disconnect the solar panel and check before and early morning again. If there is a stark difference you may need a higher specification charge controller. Also (3) make sure the solar panel is charging the batteries to their full capacity. A proper panel should deliver between .5 amps to 1 amp at hot sun to charge the batteries properly. I hear the solar input is not an effective input. The power of the gate opener is reduced through this input since the unit is compensating for this low power input. As you have explained I would condemn the solar input. Connect the 110 volt and connect the 24 volts to the battery input. The 110 charges the batteries to full power and when power goes you have the fully charged 24 volts to take over. Also, sounds as though your solar kit is stronger than the ones in the Aleko kit. The solar remains a great option since it is the main quality of this opener. Experiment with the efficiency of the kit and when you are certain of its reliability then you can connect this option. The charge changes with the sun intensity. Dull rainy days will not allow proper charge etc. All in all it is a well designed and full featured item.

question: Is this a left or right handed saw. I am right handed. Is the blade on the left or right? Thanks.
answer: Blade's on the right side. If you are right handed you will have plenty of saw dust in your face using a left handed saw. The worst part is the danger of dropping the saw to your side after a cut is finished. A left handed saw puts the blade close to your leg as you drop the saw and increases the risk of cutting your leg. We had this happen at work by a skilled user trying to use a lefty's saw. Changing something that he was simply accustomed to begged an accident and he found it one miserable day and did serious damage to his leg. It was ugly! Use right side blade for right-hand, left side for lefty when possible. If your situation requires something different you should determine to use extra caution until finished.

question: The screw that holds the faucet on the handle came out and got lost. Can anyone please tell me what kind of screw to replace it with? It was red.
answer: Okay, I'm pretty sure this is what you are facing. First, the red/blue "plug" that you lost was simply an indicator showing a turn of the handle to the right (red) would turn on the hot water; a turn to the left(blue) is, of course, the cold. Inside the hole is a fitting that accepts a hex tool that put into the fitting will tighten a loose handle (or, I suppose will allow the handle to be removed). I have never actually removed the handle, but have tightened the handle many times. If you look into the hole with a flashlight, you can barely see the fitting into which the hex tool will fit. My recollection is that you must use a 5/32" hex, and you must be careful not to "strip" the fitting -- I've done that on other plumbing fixtures and they are really tough to replace - at that point you might as well replace the faucet. By the way Pfister has an 800 number with courteous people from what I remember. Hope this helps; Good luck!

question: Will the mop touch the wall and damage the wall?
answer: A wet mop against the wall could cause mold and mildew on the wall where it touches. I do not know of any type of hanger that would prevent the mop from touching the wall. I always take some plastic and thumbtack it to the wall in a square behind where the mops/brooms will touch. The mop will even dry quicker, I think. It will even protect the wall from a dry mop that might have oily residue on it. When you take the mop, etc. down to use, take a minute and clean the plastic with a wet wipe or Clorox wipe.

question: I have just installed ours and it also swivels around to the bottom. How do you correct this?
answer: The shower arm and the filter body both have NPT threads. These are both tapered threads. In order for the filter to stop spinning, the nut has to be deep enough into the threads of the shower arm. Otherwise the nut will allow the filter body to keep spinning. Just hold the filter body in the position that you want it and tighten the nut until the filter body doesn't spin any more. Then tighten it a little more so that the threads seal against each other. It is a good idea to use teflon tape on the threads of the shower arm to make sure the threads seal properly and so that you can remove it later if you need to. This is not a job for tightening the nut by hand. You may want to use two pairs of pliers; one pair to hold the shower arm and the other one to turn the nut so that the shower arm doesn't turn inside the wall and so you can get the proper tightness. I hope this helps.

question: i put in an eight digit code like it said then pressed the pound button then locked it then reput the eight digit code and pressed the star button but wont open
answer: Gently pry open the plastic "Stack-On" logo plate to expose the key override. Open the safe and remove the key. Once opened, there's a red button on the right side; press and hold for about 2-3 seconds. The far right AMBER light will stay on. Enter your new combination, at least 3 digits long, then press "#" sign. Wait for it to accept the new code (all lights off). With the safe door still open, try out the new code to confirm it works. If not, check the freshness of the batteries and then try again. Hope this helps!

question: What is the width when open?

The only negative we found on this ladder was the brittle plastic feet and side caps which seem prone to having cracked in shipping during the winter when we purchased ours. question: What does a rapid, irregular flashing green light mean?
answer: Sounds like the cord or connecting device is not making good contact. The outlet may not be installed properly if this happens to all devices. The light comes on when the device is actually drawing current. If the light is blinking, the draw is intermittent, unless it is a faulty outlet. Try different devices. If they all have the irregular flashing light, then it is likely a faulty outlet or installation of the outlet. If some have a steady green light, then it is the device or cord that is causing the intermittent connection.

question: do you need a new charger or will your old one work

question: Could you use this to remove chain link fence posts?
answer: Most chain link fence posts are set in concrete. This would not work in that instance. If it's not set in concrete you may be able to use this if you can fashion some way to secure the pipe to a chain. It could be a piece of 3/8" flat steel plate with a slightly oblong hole in it for the pipe and another hole for a hook. When set over the pipe and lifted by the hook hole, the plate angles up and the oblong hole tightens against the pipe. The harder you pull the tighter it gets. If the pipe is really deep or set very strongly it might bend the pipe a little but probably not. Again, if it's set in concrete you won't get it out with a puller.

question: Any advantage over a traditional power strip or surge protector with an on/off switch?
answer: Yes, under certain circumstances. 1) If you have a device (such as a floor steam cleaner) that does not have an on/off switch, this can become the defacto on/off switch allowing you more flexibility in the use of the device and less wear and tear on your outlets. 2) For devices in the kitchen or bathroom where a surge protector could be dangerous. 3) chargers - for tablets, cell phones, etc -- allows me to leave the charger plugged in and turn off the power when not actually using the charger. In my case, this helps me NOT misplace my charger - which happens when I just unplug it and someone moves it on me. ;) | I like these because they have a ground (3 prongs). Several "cheaper" models and some not cheaper only offer a polarized plug (2 prongs) and therefore limit the type of appliances/devices you can use on them.

question: There are no instructions in the box. How did you know how to load the batteries?
answer: The flashlight requires three batteries. If you unscrew the back plate and turn the butt end down the battery pack will fall out. The three AA batteries will go into the battery pack with the negative end (-) or flat end against the spring. Two of the batteries will go one way and the third will go in upside down compared to the other two. The battery pack has a little knob in the center versus an indention on the other end. The pack goes into the flashlight barrel, knob end first (toward the light) and the indention end toward the screw on back plate. I hope this helps. If you still have trouble, just ask and I will be glad to try and help.

question: What is maximum height for top step when being used as a stepladder?
answer: When set up as a stepladder, the "nominal" step-to-step distance is 12 inches. On my Werner MT-22, I measured the actual floor-to-step height as follows: Step 1: 11-1/2" Step 2: 22-3/4" Step 3: 34" Step 4: 45-1/2" Step 5: 56-1/4" Step 6: 67-3/4" Step 7: 79" Step 8: 90-1/2" Top Step: 102" I expect that the step-to-step distances would be the same (or very close to same) on the MT-13, MT-17, and MT-26, although the number of steps would of course be different. By the way, it's a superb ladder! Stable, rugged, versatile, easy to set up, easy to store, and (worth saying again) very stable. Well worth the price.

question: what is the difference from a joiner or a joiner/planer?
answer: A joiner is used priomarily to provide square,finished board edges. If a thickness planer is not available , the operator may try using the joiner to reduce thickness of a board up to 6 inches wide by running the board across the joiner blades by pressing down and feeding the board manually. This will provide imperfect thickness throughout the board. The thickness planer applies uniform pressure on the board as it is automatically fed across the blades and thus provides precision thickness. Usually, boards up to 12 inches in width can be planed.

question: On the bulb is says CAUTION Do not use with dimmers. My question is why not? What happens?
answer: LEDs require a constant, maximum voltage. Dimmers obviously don't supply a constant voltage and, in fact, may not even supply the maximum at "full on;" that is, even with a dimmer not at a reduced setting, the bulb might still not light at all. However, there are special dimmable LED bulbs so keep searching! (With energy-saving, non-incandescent becoming mandatory, this issue of bulbs being incompatible with dimmers is getting corrected pretty quickly.)

question: does this work if one has an answering system?
answer: Yes, it sends outbound calls from the land line you connect it to. It would be the same as someone picking up the phone and making a call. If you were referring to the inbound call from this device, the answering machine will pick up and the device will deliver the message but since no one is responding it will hang up and call the next programmed number. It continues to do this until someone acknowledges the message by keying in one of two sequences (*0 to disable system or # to acknowledge and keep the system active so it will call again in 30 minutes if the alarm situation is still present).

question: Can I use this to hang a mirror over a fire place?
answer: It would be risky. I understand that this epoxy has good shear strength, however, you have to consider what you are bonding it to. If the back of the mirror is smooth, the epoxy might not grab the microscopic "valleys" in the back of the mirror, thus poor adherence. Also, keep in mind that the mirror is in a vertical position, so you would have to hold it and press it up against the wall for at least 1.5 hours for it to set, and it still won't be totally cured until hours later. A heavy mirror makes it even more risky. There is nothing like mechanical fastening (anchor and bolt) in brick or mortar with a cable on the back of the mirror (the trust factor increases). You don't want to be abruptly woken up by a loud crash because the epoxy failed eh? Also, the epoxy will be difficult to get off your fireplace. This is all my opinion and may not be 100% pure science.

question: I'd like to ask if the motion sensor will turn on lights from completely off state. Previous posting was not fully answered.
answer: Hmmm... ok I'll try to explain. On top of this 250 watt transformer is a mechanical timer and a switch to turn on/off the "merlin" system. Your choices are as follows: 1 use the "merlin" system or don't use the "merlin" system. With the "merlin" system on it uses the motion sensor to activate the lights from 100% brightness with motion activity or only 10% brightness(glow) when no motion is detected. The photo eye on bottom or transformer determines when the merlin system will activate....so at dusk the merlin system turns lights on slowly to about 10% provided that the motion sensor doesn't detect motion. But if motion sensor detects motion the merlin system will go to 100% bulb brightness. Keep in mind that if you choose to have the mechanical timer turn lights on and off they will be at full 100% brightness. With timer set to specific on/off times it will overide merlin activation except when dark outside because then Merlin system will use photo sensor inside motion sensor to determine if it can dim lights to 10%. (confused yet) After reading your question again the answer would be NO. The motion sensor is not intended to be a security spotlight... the "Merlin" system will only turn lights on from a dim 10% power state to full brightness 100% IF it detects motion. Why would you purchase this system when you can buy a motion activated flood light for less than $15.00 ???

question: what is the neck size ? 3.5 or 4" ?
answer: the neck size is 3.5". However, it's not like the older style light kits that sit "inside" the base of the ceiling fan. On the older style fans, you would remove the cover from the bottom of the fan, then the light kit would slide up into the fan base and you would secure the kit with two or three screws. This light kit sits "flush" against the bottom of the ceiling fan base. There should be a "knockout" in the center of your ceiling fan base. Once you take out that centerpiece from the fan base, the light kit has a threaded part on top that goes into that centerpiece and is held there by the locknut. The wires also go through that center piece where they attach to the wiring for the fan. So whether you have a ceiling fan with a 3.5" or 4" base, it shouldn't really matter because the light kit is going to sit flush against that. Hopefully I didn't confuse you with all this. Hope this helps.

question: I like these bulbs but I need to IC Rating since insulation will be in contact. What can you recommend?
answer: Hello. I don't remember the IC rating for these lights. The Gu10 bulbs they recommend get very hot. I wouldn't put insulation up against these lights because I believe there not rated. They do make covers out of flame retardantI rock wool type material . They are very pricey. In my situation my lights were installed in a 2nd floor where the air space is vented . So I built air tight boxes that went over the top of them . Or the heat / AC would've been sucked out. So i built boxes out of 1/2" Owens Corning FOAMULAR board. That I got at home depot. A 1/3 of the cost of the premade covers they sell for this aIpplication . I bought it in a 1/2" plywood size sheet. I made sure that my light were set dead center of the joists. I cut pieces to make boxes. 18" L x 18" H x 15" W. I siliconed then screwed them together like if it were wood. Siliconed the seems and let dry. I placed them over the cans cutting a slit for the electric wire and siliconed them down over the light to the drywall . Then I spray foamed the edges and the hole made for the electric wire. Totally air tight . Very inexpensive to do . Hope this helps you.

question: Will it fit my Ryobi 18 Volt Circular Saw?
answer: Hello Tina, I don't have enough information to answer your question. I would need to know the model of your Ryobi saw. The two most important bits of information are: 1) the diameter of the blade and, 2) the diameter for the arbor which fits in the hole in the middle of the blade. For this Oldham blade these dimensions are: 5-1/2" blade diameter and 5/8" arbor diameter. You can check the instruction manual for your saw to find these dimensions. If you don't have the manual, you can go to: www dot ryobitools dot com/catalog/power_tools/all_saws (replace the word dot with periods and no spaces). Check the Service and Support link for your model, or go to the web page for your model, and you may find a link there for the manual, or the specifications for your model. Good luck.

question: The feed stops and the yellow section jump up making a thumping sound. Feed then continues. Happens every 4 inches plus or minus. What is cause?
answer: I assume that the yellow section you refer to is the cutting head. If the head is locked down, it really shouldn't move. Assuming that the gears, chains and bearing are okay, my intuition would be that you're doing too big of a cut in a single pass or this is a first pass on a board that has too much thickness variation. If that doesn't seem to be the case, I'd bet it's worn out bearings. I don't use that machine anymore, but I always have a spare set of bearing because that go out fairly frequently. If I recall, they aren't too expensive and you can easily replace them yourself if you're somewhat mechanically inclined. You should be able to visually inspect them. Instead of be perfectly round they become somewhat oblonged.

question: How big in circumference is this lite?
answer: You're asking for circumference? Here goes... Anyway, this light is delineated as having these dimensions by Amazon in its packaging: 2.1 x 7.2 x 10.8 inches. There is extra space at the top of it, and the 2.1 is no doubt the thickness. This means that the light fits in a square of about 7 inches by 7 inches. This means that the radius of an inscribed circular figure is 3.5 inches. Circumference of a circle is C=2(∏)(r), so the circumference of this light in inches is approximately 2(∏)(3.5) = 22 inches.

question: My kindle charger end isn't connecting to the kindle fire, would this hold the end in place and make contact and charge?

question: Can I use this with an on off switch with option to have turn on with the switch as well as set to just motion control ? Really need to know

The light can be turned on or off manually at night only. Manual Override Mode (to keep lights on): Flip the switch twice slowly (off-on-off-on) within 1-2 secs. ■ Evening Timer (to keep lights on for a set period each night): Flip the switch three times slowly (off-on-off-on-off- on) within 2-3 secs. ■ To Resume Auto Mode : Switch power off for at least 10 seconds, then back on.

question: Can this light be used in a completely enclosed fixture. I have several lights I would love to replace the bulb and forget.

question: I have a watts plt-5 pre charged at 40 will the det replace it?
answer: Yes, I believe it should. They are both the same 3/4" male thread and made for the same size potable water systems. I'd google the watts customer service number if you needed to find out for sure. But looking at their specs, the biggest difference between DET and PLT series appears to be the DET is made in the USA, while the PLT is made in Taiwan. There are a few internal design differences and max pressure differences, but nothing a normal homeowner would worry about for residential usage. As far as the psi goes, the pre-charge really means nothing. You should adjust that pressure to match the pressure on the house side of your regulator (cold/resting pressure, ie water heater not running and relieve the overpressure with a quick run of both faucets before testing). Usually should be around 30-50 psi, depending on who you talk to. Which is likely why Watts set it around 40. So check your house pressure and adjust accordingly. You might need to adjust your regulator, but either way make the expansion tank match the house pressure.

question: to 73 degrees and it kicks the motor on and repeats this many times. Can't be good for the motor. Any solutions.
answer: When you set the thermostat to the approximate temperature of the room (as detected by the internal thermometer of the thermostat), and are in the Auto mode, the cooler will switch on and off every time that temperature goes up a degree or two. If you don't like the recycling rate, turn the thermostat up a few degrees in the Auto mode and it will usually come on less often. However, this recycling is not doing much damage to the fan motor of your evaporative cooler so long as the belt is in good shape and set properly and the shaft of the squirrel cage fan is properly oiled. The belt should have about two inches of play at a point halfway between the motor pulley and the squirrel cage fan pulley. The fan shafts should be oiled at the beginning of the cooling season, sometime halfway through the cooling season, and at the end of the cooling season. Only a few drops of 3 in 1 or similar oil is need each time. Assuming you do not have sealed bearings on this shaft, there is an oil hole on each end of the shaft with a little spring loaded lid on them. At the end of the season, be sure that the pads and inside of the cooler are COMPLETELY dry before covering it to avoid rust. At the start of the season, with the power off, turn the large pulley on the fan shaft to ensure that it is free and turns easily before turning on the fan. If the fan is stuck, it will most likely burn out the motor. The motor is designed to start and stop as often as necessary and these starts and stops don't cause much wear unless the fan belt is set wrong. It is very similar to a refrigerator or air conditioner which cycles on and off when temperature changes are needed and will last many years doing so. Both are just motors.

question: Do you carry this valve for a 1" water main? If so how much? Also, are these compatible with ADT Pulse systems? Thanks.
answer: Just an FYI - I am not a plumber - although I do most of my own plumbing. This was not the most difficult thing to install - however a lot of thought in to how to install it had to go in. Most plumbers who I showed it to thought I was wasting my money and it seemed as if they thought that well -if you can afford one of those than you can afford the $500 for me to install it. I installed it (and my entire water filter system in less than 4 hours - but I had to use all copper since that is the code here). Most water systems enter the house on different size pipes. At first I thought ours was 1" - but I am glad I checked and saved the return charge - since ours was only " however - most that I have seen are 3/4" or 1" pipes I decided to add this to the end of our water filtration system (since most of the water goes through there) and I made sure to installed a union fitting onto both ends in case I need to remove it for repair or replacement. Both ends of the brass fitting are threaded (I guess in case you need to remove it you don't have to un-solder it). As for the ADT pulse system - I am assuming that as long as you get the one that z-wave - than that should work. I can't say for sure since I don't use ADP (hate monthly charges) and use the Mi Casa Verde VeraLite Home Controller (http://www.amazon.com/Mi-Casa-Verde-VeraLite-Controller/dp/B007005364/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1389557420&sr=8-1&keywords=Mi+Casa+Verde+VeraLite+Home+Controller)

question: How effective are these at blocking heat?
answer: This will block the air flow from a forced air heat vent. They come in different sizes for different size vents. Order one that fits the vent(s) you have. You can purchase a smaller one to block only a partial vent. However, they are not very strong magnetically, so if there is any air pressure at all, it could be ineffective. The more vents you have blocked, the more pressure you have in the system. If you are blocking a lot of vents, it might be better to turn down/off the heater altogether and use an area heater for the area you need the heat. Another solution is to buy an adjustable heat vent that has a lever that you manually adjust the air flow for one vent. Warning of caution though, don't block more than 50% of you vents, this will cause too much pressure and possibly cause a problem blower motor or blow a hole in the the ducting, both of which can cost a lot of money to fix. Even worse, over working the blower motor and backing up the heat in the heater could cause a fire.

question: Can this be connected to both faucet and fridge ice maker? will this provide enough pressure for the fridge?
answer: I got this! Yes, it can be connected and I will explain the process below. It's fine for fridge pressure, but depending on how your ice maker operates will determine how the ice cubes end up. My Frigidaire has a timer that will open up the water line for about 30 seconds, then close it no matter what. If the tank on the RO is low, this results in a couple smaller ice cubes for one or two batches. No big deal, just wanted to make you aware of it. Now, to connect the RO to an ice maker, I have an easier (and cheaper) solution than what Watts offers. Amazon sells most of the parts, but you'll probably end up having to buy the rest from your local hardware store. However, I do recommend that before you follow the process below, install the RO first and use it for a couple days to make sure there aren't any leaks. Once you're confident the RO is up-and-running properly, then you can go ahead and connect your icemaker. First, decide what type of line you want to run from the RO to the fridge. You can't use copper (because it affects the cleanliness of the RO water), so you can use either polyethylene tubing (the thin stuff that uses compression fittings) or a flexible PVC/stainless line (with metal connectors on either end). Take my advice and go with the PVC option...it's less likely to leak. Besides your supply line, you're going to need a 1/4" Tee with Quick Connect fittings, a 1/4" shut-off valve with Quick Connect fittings, and about a foot of 1/4" polyethylene tubing. I found them all on Amazon, but they'll probably be a little cheaper at a hardware store. Links to the tee and the valve are below for visual reference. http://www.amazon.com/Watts-PL-3003-Push-Tee-4-Inch/dp/B000BVMY9S/ref=sr_1_9?ie=UTF8&qid=1370103689&sr=8-9 http://www.amazon.com/Watts-PL-3011-Push-Valve-4-Inch/dp/B000BO585M/ref=sr_1_13?ie=UTF8&qid=1370103689&sr=8-13 Finally, and this is the hardest item to find, you need a Quick Connect adapter. This will allow you to easily adapt a Quick Connect fitting to a threaded 1/4 connector. In my experience, smaller hardware stores (Ace, True Value, etc.) that sell Culligan water filters also sell these connectors. Amazon has them, but not through Prime... http://www.amazon.com/Culligan-Qc-ak-Quick-Connect-Adapter/dp/B002T4PEC4/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1370104179&sr=8-1 Once you've got all your parts, turn off the water supply to the RO. Turn on the faucet and let the tank completely drain. Once that's done, cut the blue line marked "faucet" that runs from the top right of RO system to the faucet. Doesn't matter where you cut it, just somewhere in the middle. Take the cut ends of the blue "faucet" line and reconnect them to the two ends on the tee quick connect adapter. Then, cut 6" of polyethylene tubing and insert one end into the top portion of the tee. Now, insert the other end of the polyethylene tubing into one end of the Quick Connect shut-off valve, and your Culligan Quick Connect adapter into the other end of the shut-off valve. Screw on your flexible PVC tubing, run to the back of the fridge, connect, and that's it! When you open up the water line for the first time after it's connected to the icemaker, make sure the shut-off valve you just installed is closed. Let the tank fill up completely, then open the shut-off valve to let water flow to the icemaker. Check for leaks and as long as you did everything right, you'll be enjoying incredible ice in no time.

question: Two questions: a) does the saw just "sit" on the base --- without mechanical fasteners b) does the foot pedal "latch" when depressed for moving?
answer: The base is designed for an older Delta unisaw or shaper without a cast iron base (20 3/4 X 20 3/4 inches). The unisaw actually sits down into the frame and rest on the four corner base supports. The unisaw does not need anything to hold it down...it just sits inside the frame. The 50-289 does not work with an old old unisaw or shaper with a cast iron base or with the newer 36-LX52 Delta unisaw. You have to buy the 50-257 mobile base to fit the new dual front handle unisaw. I cut a piece of 1/2 inch plywood and placed it into the frame for the saw to sit on so the sawdust would not fall on the floor, but would be trapped inside as if the saw was sitting on the concrete. The foot pedal when depressed for moving stays in the depressed position until you release it with your toe. It works very well and is engaged by simply using your toe to raise or lower the saw. I am very pleased with it.

question: can this be used to sharpen knives
answer: here's the thing--you can "sharpen" with basically anything abrasive that's harder than the steel you're sharpening. Aluminum oxide and silicon carbide abrasives won't work as well on "super steels" (e.g. CPM S30V, which contain vanadium carbides, pretty hard stuff that really only cuts quickly on diamond or cubic boron nitride) but unless you're going for a mirror polish anything harder than steel will work just fine. The soft backing on micro mesh is great for some applications, and it could give you an interesting 'convex' shape (like using a buffing wheel or belt grinder) if you really work on your technique, but I think you'll find that something like 3M (or other brand) lapping 'films' work much better for maintaining a consistent angle. Sandpaper can work in a pinch, but it loads too much to use dry and it's pretty messy when wet, I'd recommend the "film" sheets over paper if you're serious about starting a real sharpening routine.

question: do you have instructions for the extension kit?
answer: Yes. There are 2 diiferent miter saw base configurations & therefore 2 slightly different instruction sets. Miter saws with u-shaped supports The extension kit can be used on either side or both sides of the saw. Assemble as follows: 1. Install self-tapping stud into the hole underneath the saw, threading in the shorter end using a " (13mm) wrench. 2. Install the stop-washer ad screw into the rod nearest the front. 3. Clamp the rods against the miter saw unit by tightening the clamping bracket nut. 4. Align end plate with top of work surface and tighten locknuts. Miter saws with holes: 1. Slide rods into the holes in the saw base. 2. Align end plate with top of work surface and tighten locknuts. 3. Insert the self-tapping screw into the hole to lock the rods in place.

question: would these suits protect against ebola?
answer: I thing the question is pretty serious myself. These suits are designed to stop liquids, and as far as I can tell are the same suits being used by MSF (Doctors without Borders) in africa. The suit is only a part of the solution, it must be used with 2 layers of gloves, proper eye protection, and proper mask. Just as important as the suit itself is proper knowledge of its use. dressing and undressing in the proper order is even more important than the materials the protective clothing are made of. MSF has a website with free download of books they have published (in english and french) with every bit of information you will ever need on control of hemmoragic fevers such as ebola. It is much better to buy several cheap suits that can be disposed of if torn or overly contaminated than it is to spend a lot of money on one big fancy one.

question: Recommended RPM speed for drilling 1/4" diameter into 1/16" aluminum sheeting?

(Just dip the bit in a can of water.) If you find that the bit is seizing, sharpen the bit or slow down the RPM's a little. "Cool Tool" is an excellent lubricant for aluminum. question: What, exactly, does the gate "kit" come with?
answer: The kit comes with top and bottom rails that you will have to cut to size with a hack saw. The side rails are curved and the top and bottom rails fit into them. It comes with self tapping screws to complete the rail connection. There is a truss wire with connectors that run from one corner of the frame to another. The chain link provided is enough to cover the full width so you have to size it to fit the size of your frame by simply "unscrewing" one link row. There are connectors that hold the chain link to the frame. It comes with the gate side of 2 hinges. Unfortunately, they did not fit the pole side of the hinges that I bought, so I had to buy the gate side of the hinges to fit. Finally, it includes a gate latch. I'm happy with it since I could make it the exact size that I needed for my garden. Hope this helps.

question: can the sensor probe wire be extended I need to install 60 feet away from controller
answer: I've not used them at that distance, but it should be fine. A k-type thermocouple produces about 41 microvolts/degree C. A typical op-amp (input for the PID controller) has an input bias current of say 45nA (for the LM324). 1000 ft of 24 gauge copper wire has a resistance of about 26 ohms. 45nA x 26 ohms is about 1.1 microvolts. That's about a 2% error for a 500 foot run (there and back) of really small wire. So 60ft shouldn't be a problem. Your error for 60 feet would be closer to 0.34%. Besides all this, the PIDs are self calibrating, so if the PID works as expected, it should be able to calibrate for a large portion of that anyway.

question: How wide it the opening you cut in the downspout to install this?
answer: The vertical downspout must be cut completely in half about 1/2" minimum above the height of the rain barrel or where the filler hose from the downspout to the rain barrel will enter the rain barrel. Some rain barrels fill from the top, and others from somewhere on the side of the barrel. I cut my downspout about 4 1/2" above the barrel to make room for the downspout diverter to fit above the height of the barrel since my barrel fills both ways and I wasn't sure if I wanted to fill from the top or side. Then you cut an equal amount ( or what is needed to refit the lower part of the downspout) off the lower downspout you had cut off to attach to the bottom of the diverter, so the excess water can run past the diverter when the barrel is full so the water will drain out into the yard as before the diverter was installed. Without the second cut the lower downspout will drag the ground when you try to reinstall the lower downspout unless the opening was way off the ground originally. If the upper cut is too low, the water won't run uphill to fill the rain barrel and the water will all run down the downspout as if the diverter wasn't there. I guess you can't make it too high unless it's so high the hose won't reach the opening in the barrel. In all, I cut a section of about 8 1/2" out of the original downspout to make room for the diverter and it's about four inches above my rain barrel. I didn't need to use the adapters that come with the diverter kit, but that could add as much as 3 inches to the length of the diverter once completed so assemble the diverter the way it's going to be installed in the downspout and measure. That will be the minimum amount you need to cut out of the existing downspout to make it fit. As long as it's about the filler in the rain barrel but will still reach, it will work just fine. Hope this helps.

question: What size is the bulb base and is it easily replaceable with an LED bulb of equivalent size?
answer: It's an E11 used only for small halogen bulbs. I don't believe there is any other bulbs that use an E11 socket. You can adapt an E11 to E12 (candelabra base). I replaced the socket with a standard E19 socket. The other limiting factors are the diameter of the shade opening (small) and its depth. I was able to get 40W equiv LED ceiling fan bulb to fit. If you go that way, be sure to get a bulb rated for enclosed fixtures. In short, it's possible, but difficult. The manufacturer needs to update the light assembly since a 75W or 100W halogen uses up to 10X what an equivalent LED bulb would, has a much shorter life, and produces unecessary heat.

question: nitrates
answer: Works by AC Filtration, so no it doesn't I checked the insert ...see below quoted from www.waterfilters.net Similar to other types of water treatment, AC filtration is effective for some contaminants and not effective for others. AC filtration does not remove microbes, sodium, nitrates, fluoride, and hardness. Lead and other heavy metals are removed only by a very specific type of AC filter. Unless the manufacturer states that its product will remove heavy metals, the consumer should assume that the AC filter is not effective in removing them. Check http://www.filterwater.com/s-7-nitrate-filters.aspx Hope this helps :)

question: Would I need to remove the gate's latch? I guess the opener can't unlatch the gate but want to be sure i understnd the process before I order!
answer: Hope I can help. The gate opener only opens and closes the gate stopping a point that you determine. it will not move from these settings. If you are referring to a latch and lock system the normal kind will not work with the opener. Yes you could have a normal latch that would close and secure the gate but it would have to be opened manually to open the gate. There is a electromagnetic gate latch that works well but you can only use it if your using normal ac current, the solar version will not take the load of this type of gate latch and will run the battery down faster than the solar panel can charge it. I have no latch on my gate but put a 2x6 piece of wood on my fence and the gate pushes up against the wood to keep a tight fit when closed. For security if i'm away from home at length I just wrap a chain and lock around the gate when its closed. Its a great opener but I have several helpful suggestions that the company does not explain for security, and also ease of installation if you are interested.

question: How does this mount to the ceiling? I can't see any good picture online. I was thinking it might be installed with a downrod, but don't see one.
answer: Hello there, If i remember correctly, this is installed with a steel bracket approx about 4-6 inches apart. One important factor i should mention about this product is the coupling of the main unit (the ceiling piece you can see here) with the bracket (the big circle portion at the top). If you'll notice from the last picture, about where the cylinder meets the "dome" for the lighting, you have to hold up the light and attach these onto the bracket. It may not look complicated but it was hard doing it by myself (as the light portion is quite heavy even without the crystal bulbs attached). Be aware you will have to attach the electrical along with holding up the light and finding the holes to the bracket all at the same time! Buy a strand of metal wire to attach through the holes during the process to hold up the light. Additionally, be aware of the hydrogen bulbs you place in the lamp. Make sure you buy lower wattage (and not the big bulky LED energy saving bulbs) as they may/may not fry the little transformer in the light. Hope this helps!

question: My existing motor is a 3 wire, what is this one?
answer: This is a perminent split capacitor (PSC) motor and requires a run capacitor. This motor will have 4 wires but will work fine. The 2 Brown wires go to the capacitor, the white & black go to common (L1) & run (or L2)respectivily. Two other leads will allow reverse rotation. You don't need to charge the capacitor - that happens instantly.

question: Can I use this with 20x10w halogen bulbs? I would probably need to get two of these as I'm replacing two transformers which I think blew out
answer: Let's see, 20x10w = 200w; the transformers are rated 150 w. If these were real transformers, there would be no issue. BUT ! These are "electronic" transformers; I am not sure how they work (or why !) but they seem to be very sensitive to being matched capacity to load. Thus, you might be better off with 2 x 100w transformers. Note too, that these are sold as "12v" transformers; the reality is they are 11 volts +/- , I think, 10%. 9.6 volts is " in spec" ! Halogen lamps are designed for 12-14 volts, 11 volts results in noticeably dim lights.

question: Image shows a large saw being used on the work bench. Can saws be attached to the work bench?
answer: The top of the bench is about 3" thick, honeycomb thermoplastic, with a variety of clamping points. I usually clamp wood to the surface, and use my power tools in my hands. But the bench will hold hundreds of pounds and is very stable (I have stood on it - 220 lbs). This workbench is considered a mobile workbench, and is no match for a heavy metal tool stand. And how do you define a large saw, 12" comercial table saw, or power miter saw? Say the saw weighs 50 pounds. If you can clamp or bolt the your saw to the top, in my opinon it will hold the weight and stress of cutting standard wood pieces. If you are trying to cut railroad ties, it is probably not the right bench.

question: Outdoor Installation: Has anyone installed this heater outdoors?

We are not talking cute little electrons here!!! We're talking all that GE has got, all at once. Seriously. DO NOT ATTEMPT. It would cost too much anyway to build a waterproof enclosure big enough to include servicing area, as well as the unit and filters, bringing power to it, which depending on the length of the run will necessitate a larger diameter wire, AND a special cable designed for outdoor use. question: I have a vertical thermostat, but I want to install new one horizontal. What I can do with this product?
answer: I used this product to successfully and securely mount a new thermostat horizontally in place of the original thermostat that was mounted vertically on a metal junction box that was attached to a wall stud. The package contains two plastic coverplates and one metal adapter. The metal adapter is the critical piece; it converts a vertical mount to a horizontal mount. I attached the metal adapter to the metal junction box and then attached the new thermostat to the metal adapter. Neither of the two plastic cover plates were compatible with my new thermostat so they could not be used. Since the new thermostat was smaller than the original thermostat I am left with an unsightly mess of unpainted drywall that the plastic coverplate was intended to cover. Some repainting was required to finish the job. I am not a tradesman and do not do this for a living. I tried three different Honeywell coverplates and none of them was compatible with my new Honeywell thermostat. However, this coverplate at least provided a metal adapter that allowed the new thermostat to be mounted horizontally on a vertical junction box.

question: Can you install this on a plastic pipe OUTDOORS in the rain? Do you have to wrap the pipe with more insulation and also to keep it dry or not? Thanks!
answer: Having grown up on a farm in Minnesota and used heat tapes for most of my life, the answers from my own experiences include: 1. The tape can be wrapped around plastic (PVC) pipe. 2. You have to insulate the pipe wrapped with the heat tape using foam purchased by the foot or in 6-10 foot lengths. The insulation can come in 3/4 inch or 1 inch size and you probably need the 1 inch foam insulation to cover not only the pipe but the heat tape as well. 3. The tape is sealed and will most likely get wet at some time and I've never seen this causing any problems with the tape operation. Keep in mind that this a very low voltage system and does not get burning hot, only the slightest bit warm. For that reason, the heat has to be held in just like you would when laying in bed on a cold night, you bundle up and keep the blanket over you to keep warm.

question: Will these bits fit on a dremel tool?
answer: These bits are for a drill press. You could use them with a hand drill but the hole cut would be far from the perfect hole you would get using drill press. The Dremel tool has a 1/8 inch shank which is far too small for these bits. These bits are a great deal if you have a drill press. You have to squirt water on the bit and cutting surface while drilling to keep thee bits from getting over heated. If the bit gets over heated it will lose it's temper and the diamond dust cutting edge will be lost.

question: Craftsman opener(unknown model) I press the button, lt turns red, I press the remote, remote flashes, opener LED no blink. (bat plastic out) Ideas?
answer: If your garage door opener has a "learn button" make sure to hold in in for a few seconds before releasing it. When the LED light next to the learn button lights then press and hold the remote button for a second or two. The LED light next to the learn button will flash and then will go off. The transmitter should the be programmed. I stood on a ladder next to the opener when programming for convenience. Check for battery weakness if problems persist. If your learn button is not green you may have an incompatible device.

question: Does anyone know what is the difference between this model and the 2600 Legend series and which would you recommend?
answer: 2600 has the easy mount system and the 9930 has the three bolt mounting system. There are two differences between the Waste King EZ mount system and Waste King 3-Bolt mount system garbage disposers. The 3-bolt mounting system has all stainless steel mounting components, the EZ mounting system has plastic and aluminum mounting components. The 3-bolt mounting system has a non removable hush cushion (splash guard), the EZ mounting system has a removable splash guard. There are no differences with the motors or performance. The EZ mount system is true to its name, it is indeed easier to work with than the 3 bolt system. Neither garbage disposal style is considered better than the other. They are both very durable mounting systems. It is solely a product preference.

question: TO make it work one function per week, do I program 1 on at the lift, and not program 1 off? Two timers, one tells unt to lift, other to close..??
answer: I'm not sure what you are asking. If you are using the controller to operate a chicken house door, the motor must be powered on to lift/lower and then powered off to reset for the next function (lift/lower). So, with the door closed, program the date and time you want the door to open. Then set an off time 3 to 5 minutes later to reset the motor for the close function. Then program the date and time you want the door to close by setting an on time and 3 to 5 minutes later set an off time.

question: Still can decide between this and the Wilton Tradesman. Any thoughts?
answer: Wilton used to be the standard by which all else were judged. They seem to have dropped from that position. If you want or need to beat on your vice and its contents then go for the Rigid,, or any other vice that has its tensile strength. If you hold lighter things and want one that has more flexible holding features, then consider lesser expensive weaker models. My Rigid isn't the most adapting yet I'm totally comfortable beating hard on it (its also guaranteed not to break). I thought I might buy a cheaper second vice for holding small pipes and other round things for instance. After more than a year, I still have only the Rigid. I weld, and work on heavy trucks and machinery as well as delicate electronic soldering, so far, all with the one vice.

question: Can these lights work with just a regular car battery?
answer: The lights are designed to work with 12V DC, hence they can work on the 12 V car battery. Since the car battery is very powerful (comparing to the LED power supply) the only concern may be the accidental short circuiting on wires. From there you HAVE to connect the lights from the fused car circuit (or on additional external 1A fuse immediately after car battery) and NOT DIRECTLY (without the fuse) to the car battery as it may create fire if/when the + and - wires are accidentally short circuited (or + shorts to car metal that is always -). This applies to any addition to your car electrical system so if you do not know what do you do, consult car mechanic.

question: For some reason this doesn't fire my Arrow T50 9/16" staples consistently; it doesn't sink them all the way into the wood. Am I doing something wrong?
answer: This is unlikely due to the Stapler. I purchased this stapler to build one dozen acoustic panels for my home recording studio. I was building wooden frames wherein I can place insulation and hang them like pictures. To build the frames, I used "furring strips" from Lowes. I learned that at some parts of various strips, it was simply too tough for the staples to penetrate while in others there were no problems at all. Because I was building so many, I found it worth while to purchase an electric version of this. Even that was having difficulty punching in staples in some places. Notice though, that the 9/16" will still penetrate, but just twist after some depth. It might make sense to get shorter staples; but that is no guarantee -- depending on what you're building. That said, the most likely reason the staples don't sink in fully is the wood is too dense. Furthermore, make sure to put weight on the back of the stapler as you fire off staples.

question: Weather/water proof or resistant? Does it have low powered fans or anything to control its temperature? I'm looking at this as possible substitute for the battery tender jr. But do need something that sit out in my Louisiana driveway which is exposed...
answer: Ola Fee - Neither weatherproof or resistant, strictly indoors or protected from weather under a hood. It is a solid state computer board with a fan to control its temperature in a plastic box but as I think I remarked the fan is the feature that bothered me the most because it is already making noise like it will fail at any moment. I am in less than 25% humidity (And it is glorious!) for most of the year and so electronics and much else lasts much longer but I don't even leave this unattended or on while away/sleeping and having lived in high humidity most of my life I would think its lifetime would be shorter. I have an 8 year old or so Schumacher trickle charger (small solid state, supposedly a leave-it-on the battery "smart" charger however it works poorly and sometimes not at all on 6 V batteries; I am biased against Battery tender products based on what I have read from reliable sources in magazines and online. All I can say about this is that they have gotten the charge parameters right (including desulfating) to restore (some) run down batteries, maintain frequently used batteries to extend their life (a vehicle alternator does not do so), and it does so inexpensively. I no longer believe in the use of trickle chargers or battery maintainers - as long as the battery surface is kept clean from water-conducting material (I know, hard in LA) and electrolyte levels are maintained I would rather apply one of these for several hours before intended use (even after a year of inactivity) rather than try to "maintain" a battery. "Auto Restorer" magazine runs pretty good articles on this whole issue and you may be able to find relevant articles at a library or from a friend who subscribes. Best of luck.

question: Where to mount (20' x 25' x 8' woodshop) - tools along 2 walls - workbench in center - mainly sanding dust..
answer: The most optimal spot is hanging from the ceiling near the long wall of a rectangular shop with the intake of the unit located at about 1/3 of the long wall and the exhaust pointing with the long wall towards the opposite corner of that long wall. This will provide the most efficient room circulation. You choose the mounting spot so that the direction of dust flow within the room is complementary to where you normally stand. In other words, you don't want to stand in a direct line between the dust source and the intake because that means your lungs filter the air before the air filter unit which is obviously bad. In general, you want to stand in a location that is downwind of the exhaust path of the collector. For sanding the above recommendation is still optimal overall however, I also recommend collecting most of the dust at the source with a downdraft table and vacuum because the dust is so fine, you don't want to transfer that dust around the room. You can also use a cheap smaller air filter unit (like a box fan with HVAC home filter duct tape to it) right next to your dusting station in tandem with the whole room system.

question: But is it waterproof? I was disappointed with the nearly-identical-looking Sunforce 60-LED floodlight, which died after the first rainstorm.
answer: The SL1 Solar Security Light is IP56 rated. Waterproofing is rated by the IP (International Protection) system which consists of the letters IP followed by two digits. The first digit after IP ranks a products protection against solid objects. The second digit after the IP rates a products ability to protect against liquids. The FL1 Solar Floodlight is IP56 rated. IP56 means the light is protected against dust - limited ingress (no harmful deposit) and protected against strong jets of water e.g. for use on shipdecks - limited ingress permitted. This means it should be fine for use in a rainy or wet area. Just don't let anything solid hit it (hail, debris).

question: where is the on-off switch?
answer: Sure, easy, Jeff. On the TOP there are 2 sections: the longer section contains the little LED bulbs. The other shorter section, on top, has an oblong gray shape with a sort-of slim black v-shape inside of it. With your finger TOUCH the top of the oblong shape. Voila! Light goes on. question: Will this work on a 4-D Mag Light? Thanks!
answer: These lamps are designed to emit their maximum lumens at specified voltages and amperages. A 3-D cell LED would be overdriven by the voltage and amperage of 4-D cells. It would be extremely bright for a very short amount of time. If you insist on using the LED, use only 3-D cells in the Mag Light, and use a dummy cell to take up the space. You can use another D cell, but cover both ends well with a non-conductive covering, then wrap the dummy cell in metal foil, so that you make a circuit from the end of the 3rd cell to the spring in the end cap. Now you have a 3-D cell Mag Light.

question: I plan to have a Hydronic baseboard heater at each end of the main living room, will my current lux programable electric baseboard thermostat work?

It's universal design allows it to work with both single-pole (two-wire) and double-pole (four-wire)systems, 120/240-volt systems up to 16 amps (resistive: 1,900 watts at 120 VAC/3,800 watts at 240 VAC), and line voltage (120/240-volt) The PlF2004 240volt heater draws 8 amps, two 16 amps.

question: I got two of these with a center mount glide. But with no directions and none existing on the furniture: What am I supposed to do with them?
answer: These go on both sides at the front of the drawer opening in the chest, with the long dimension perpendicular to the vertical sides of the opening and the short dimension up against the edge of the opening. The bottom of the side walls of the drawer slide on these. To install them, you'll probably have to use either a small hammer or the side of a hammer and it works best if you put a small piece of wood or something stiff and flat, even a putty knife between the glide and the hammer so you're actually distributing the load on the glide, otherwise the head of the tack in the glide will break through. If it does, you can still make the glide work by hammering the tack down with a nail set. Photo posted.

question: Which size would be best for someone who wanted to store albums in there (I.e. coin collectors, family albums.)?
answer: Certainly not the X125 which is much too small. Even the 4 bolt 1.2 cu ft. combination safe is too small for albums of any reasonable size. The 1.2 cu ft. says it all, basically the internal size is 1ft. in length X 1ft. in width X 1ft. in height . So measure your album with a 12 inch ruler and if it is longer than the ruler then it will not fit except if it is only slightly longer than the ruler and is placed diagonally in the safe. Even then it can only hold one album. No, you need something larger than a 1.2 cu ft. So the X125 - FORGET IT ENTIRELY as it is too small.

question: How far out does this light cast?
answer: I can't give an exact answer. In general, the intensity of a light decreases with the square of the distance from the light. In other words, if the distance from the light doubles, you divide the source intensity by 4. My back yard is about 1/2 acre, and this light throws out enough light so that you can see a person or animal anywhere in the yard. Subjectively, I would say the light is fairly "bright" for at least 100 feet; but, as mentioned earlier, the intensity drops off with distance. I've been pleased with this light. question: I plan to use the Eemax EMT2.5 to feed hot water to my energy star dishwasher, which requires very hot water (145 deg F). Does it work? Thx!
answer: It works well. In fact, if you use a central water heater, the water is first heated by the central water heater. The water in the pipes cools and then is sent to the dishwasher where it is heated again by the dishwasher. This heater is actually an energy and money saver. We hooked it up the cold water pipe under the sink and tee'd the outlet to the hot water feed to the sink and also to the dishwasher. No more waiting for hot water at the sink and then wasting energy for the hot water that cools in the piping to the sink.

question: why does the flush vavle close to soon sometimes?
answer: Hi Ruth. Most all new Kohlers are a water saver style toilet, and are designed to deliver two types of flushes. First is the quick flush for urine, and that means you push down then quickly release the handle. Less water is used so there is a water savings over emptying the tank. Second flush type is for solids, and you simply hold down on the handle until the flush is complete. All the water in the tank is used, but the newer tanks are smaller, so less water is used compared to the toilets of the 50's and 60's. It's all about water savings. No one thinks to tell you, eh? Good luck on the flush from now on. ...Jeff...

question: Will it work with LED bulbs?
answer: I have this connected to incandescent pot lights. When you push the on switch there is a slight pause from when the light comes on to when the light is fully bright. Because of that, I would use them with dimmable LEDs. Leviton's own documentation warns that using incandescent DIMMER switches with LED bulbs may result in inconsistent performance, and that they are not UL safety rated for use with LED bulbs. But this isn't really a dimmer switch, it's either on or off. Most of what I have read regarding using standard wall switches (incandescent) for LED bulbs only talk about performance loss at low power, not about safety issues. To be safe, though, I would ask an electrician, or consult the manufacturer's (lighting fixture) documentation.

question: I'm a little worried..So I wonder whether the tool will work normally if you plug it into a power transformer 220 / 110V, 3000 VA (kW)? I'm not sure how much of influence will take affect to the frequency ... Because, as you already know, the standard...
answer: Obviously, it must be selected for 110V operation as 220v would burn it out rather dramatically. But 50 Hz is the frequency in Europe, 220V here in the US is still 60 Hz. In fact house power arrives as a 220V (60 Hz) circuit that is split into 2 x 110V lines (still 60 Hz) - there is no change in frequency. Secondly, there are only certain types of motors which are affected by frequency, ...these typically being so-called 'synchronous motors'. I've run saws from my generator all day - which uses a substantially square wave output (true sine wave generation is more expensive) - no problem. A power transformer by the way does not change the frequency - unless it is also a converter having batteries and active circuits for regenerating the sine wave output. I'm an electronic engineer by trade. Hope that helps.

question: Can this be used to remove several layers of old paint from a door? Also layers of stain and poly? Is there a link for blade replacement? Thank you!
answer: Sandblasting a door would probably be the best way to remove old paint, it will get it down to the grain rather quickly and you won't disfigure the frame. If you sand blast it, you will think it's never been painted before. You can get a blast tank at Harbor Freight on sale for under a hundred dollars. You will need a good compressor, at least a 60 gallon. I would recommend getting a Two Stage compressor like an Ingersoll Rand as they will last a long time and have plenty of power for all types of air tool applications. They are pricey, about $1000. Or just pay someone else to sand blast the door for you, probably $80. If the door is off the hinges this will scrape it down, but anything 3D will be problematic. If you hit a nail or a screw in the door it will chip the blade and leave a high trail where the chip is. The only other way to do something like this would be to get a wire brush for a drill or angle grinder. A Cubic Zirconium Flop Disc isn't too bad either, they are about $13, they would shred any paint off but they are going to leave spirals in the wood. I've seen guys use a Heat Gun and a Scraper to heat the paint and just scrape it off too. Good Luck with your project.

question: Does it realy have true variable speed?
answer: It has variable speed but bear in mind that the speed is controlled by the trigger. The closer you pull the trigger to the drill body, the faster the chuck will turn. However, If by "true", you mean is there a dial where you can set the exact speed ie. 300 rpm or 350 rpm then the answer is no. This feature is more likely found on rotary tools like Dremels, some drill presses and milling machines. I am not aware of any variable speed hand drills that have scales which would enable you to dial in exact speeds. If exact speed is a necessity, then you might want to research rotary tools, bench tools which have a dial that can be set or tools that have a digital display that tells you how fast the chuck is turning. Additionally, I don't know what materials you plan to drill. This drill's range is 0-550 rpm which may or may not be suitable for your intended purpose. I recommend that you study the numerous drill speed and feed guides available on the web to determine if this drill has the best speed range for your project or whether you need a drill with a higher rpm range. It may also be helpful to do a search of materials, material thicknesses, hole sizes, suggested bit lubricants and drill types to see what tradespeople and manufacturers recommended. You can easily ruin costly materials by drilling them at the wrong speed or quickly dull expensive drill bits by using the wrong bit for the material, exerting too much pressure on the bit or not using lubricant. Talk to people who have drilled the same or similar materials. Ask to see if they have any scrap that you can use for test purposes. There is no single drill suitable for all types of drilling. Br prepared to experiment before finally figuring out what works best for you.

question: I want to use this to protect my car headliner. Do you think it will damage the felt like material the headliner is made of when I remove the film?

If you're planning on a permanent install, it won't be the most attractive product. But, you should be ok with this as a temporary protectant. It's pretty sticky but shouldn't damage vinyl headliners. On the mouse-fur or velour type headliners, don't press it on too hard and you should still be ok. When you remove it, you'll probably have fibers attached to the sticky but it shouldn't pull it bald. You might also consider using Glad Cling Wrap from your local grocery store. question: I unplug a lamp from this receptacle and now I can't plug it back in.
answer: I bought the same product. It has a very new feature: small white plastic safety child-proof barriers that move into the interiors of the slots when nothing is plugged in. These barriers move aside when you push a plug into the socket. Sometimes you have to push the plug a little harder than normal in order to get the two plastic barriers to move aside. Note that most modern plugs now have one blade that is wider than the other and sockets like this one have one slot that is likewise wider than the other. This is a safety feature. The wider blade is for the neutral side of the circuit and the narrower blade is for the hot side. Because of the different sizes of the blades the plug cannot be put into the socket incorrectly. I think that when you tried to plug the lamp back in you were unknowingly trying to put the wider blade into the narrower slot. Turn the plug one half turn (180 degrees) and it should fit properly into the socket. Push firmly to move the safeties aside.
