question: Can I use this for the Car door hinges? My car door is very hard to open.
answer: Yes, you can. Silicone spray is a "dry" spray... meaning it won't collect excess dust and muck after you apply it and it dries. However, for door hinges, you could also consider using a white lithium grease (it comes is a spray also), which doesn't dry. True, it might ultimately collect a dust and grime, but it might also provide longer protection than silicone. That said, I've used this silicone spray on my door hinges and found it worked well at cutting out squeaking and making the door easier to open/close. If your car door is "VERY hard" to open (as you put it), there might be something out of alignment with the hinges that even lubrication might not completely fix.

answer: I replaced mine with an LED, but it wasn't as simple as replacing the bulb, and most likely voided the lifetime warranty. The Halogens were too hot and too yellow for my tastes. If you turn the halogen light on for 5 minutes, you'll need oven mitts to take the globe off. Unfortunately, I wasn't able to find an LED bulb with an E12 base that output anything close to the lumens required to be the main light source for a bedroom. The easiest of my solutions involved removing the halogen base, soldering the light wires to an led array, and attaching the led array to the light mount. I chose an LED array from Seoul Semiconductors, product number SMJD2V16W1P3-CA, because it doesn't require an external led driver as it's all built into the board of the led. The 70mm circumference ended up being a perfect fit. The lights run much cooler and are brighter than with the supplied halogen. Since the dimmer supplied with the light is meant for halogens, it's not ideal for the LEDs, and there's some noticeable flicker at low dimming levels. I am slightly concerned that the light mount plate may not provide an adequate heat sink for the led array, but I haven't had any issues yet.

question: Hi, what is the material of the collector plate? And the thermal conductance losses?
answer: Hello, The collector plate is made of aluminum. Behind the absorber there is copper tubing carrying the water or heat transfer fluid, and behind that is a reflector plate. The two plates set up a blackbody radiation cavity which enhances the transfer of heat from the absorber surface to the fluid (patent pending feature). The thermal conductance losses vary greatly depending on irradiance, collector core temperature and ambient conditions. We use the maximum equilibrium temperature difference between the core and ambient as a measure of panel efficiency which is approximately 220 deg. F, however overall system maximum equilibrium temperature difference is much lower. Thank You, Heliatos Solar

question: My unit only shows 1.1 amps maximum, even using 2.0 & 2.4 A chargers w/ Galaxy S4 & variety of cables, inc. OEM Samsung charging cable. Why?
answer: Don't know what you've looked into so far, but some initial thoughts: 1) although the charger provided may be 2 or 2.1 amps, is the GS4 itself actually rated to charge at that speed, or does it perhaps max out at a lower rate? 2) good you tried different cables, those are always a likely bottleneck - btw, the original samsung cable isn't particularly good for charging, I got higher charging amps out of monoprice and other 3rd party cables. 3) if battery is near full charge, most phones will step down to a lower charging rate - try with a fairly empty (eg 50% or less) battery to see what happens. 4) if you have another device, ideally a power-hungry tablet, see how many amps those will pull on the same chargers and cables.

question: Can it be installed with a wall thermostat?
answer: It is not designed to be installed with a thermostat, but if you were sufficiently equipped, I'm sure it's possible. In effect, it doesn't need an external thermostat as the switch functions like a thermostat in the sense that there is a temperature range at which the unit will automatically turn on and off triggered by an internal thermostat. Set at its highest point, the unit remains on and throwing heat. Set the switch anywhere in between, and the unit cycles on and off according to the temperature determined by the internal thermostat depending on how far you turn the switch. As evidence of this internal thermostat, you should also note, that this internal thermostat turns on the unit after you shut it down so as to cool down the coil automatically.

question: I am looking for a headlamp to go camping - something that will let me see my feet and the path ahead of me for a bit. Will 35 lumens do the trick?
answer: I'm a postman. I use mine for reading the mail at arm's length as I put it into a cluster box. Anything further than that, and you're going to want more lumens. This lamp would be OK inside a tent. But outside . . . One of my fellow carriers has one of these. I'll probably get one this fall once the days get shorter. ExtremeBeam's OSR-800 headlamp is one of the brightest and farthest-reaching headlamp on the market. Using a 4-mode 180-lumen LED and fully telescoping lens, this powerful headlamp can shine light to distances of 550 feet when used on high. question: I know this lathe can go on a bench top, but other than that, what lathe stand would fit?

Leveling is not a critical as with a machine lathe, but is still best practice. This lathe has enough gusto to turn pieces large enough to walk it around if they are out of balance. Not just with chunks missing, but also pieces not yet dry, with differential amounts of water through the piece. Out of balance pieces can be a little dangerous.

question: What types of pads work on this buffer? There's so many types on amazon I don't witch one will fit.
answer: Its advertised as a 7 inch buffer but since there is no guard that limits what size you can use you have a broad range of size to chose from. The arbor (threaded portion that holds the backing pad to the buffer) is a standard thread and size so almost any backing pad should fit. It also comes with a lock nut to hold backing pads that are not threaded onto the arbor. The biggest thing is dont skimp on the backing pad. Crappy backing pads can come apart when in use causing injury or damage to whatever your working on. Backing pads that dont hold the pad securely can slip and also leave a rubber skid mark and/or scratches on your work as well. The backing pad that comes with the buffer is one of the types that can slip and scar your work. GET RID OF IT! Other reviewers have had problems with the included backing pad as well. I suggest Meguiar's Self-Centering 8-Inch Rotary Buffer Backing Plate. Its sold on Amazon for $20 and has served me well for numerous jobs with this buffer. It has a velcro attachment for any front pad you want and holds it securely. The material you chose for the front pad will vary with whatever you are doing.

question: 2 questions.. 1)does it matter what type of bulbs are in my fixture? 2) can i add a third switch for same fixture?
answer: 1) if you want to use the dimming function, be sure to use dimmable lights. I use these with dimmable incandescent and led bulbs. 2) yes. This kit comes with a primary and an auxiliary switch. The auxiliary sends a signal to the primary switch to tell it what to do. If you want to add a third switch, you'll need another auxiliary switch. Also, note that the wiring for this kit is different from a traditional 3-way switch. This video helped me a lot: http://youtu.be/2vguVa58PGI To extend to a 4-way setup, you'll wire the second auxiliary switch the same way you wire the first auxiliary. I bought about 8 of these kits and found that the primary switch on two of the kits didn't work properly with the auxiliary. If you follow the video and don't get a proper result (e.g. Flickering lights when you try to use the auxiliary switch) don't burn a lot of time trying to make it work. Exchange it. I recommend practicing with a basic single switch setup first, then graduate to a secondary switch, then add the third switch. Troubleshooting the entire setup out of the gate can ruin your weekend!

question: Can this handle dimming LED lights all the way down so they are actually dim, like the incandescents? Yes, I have an LED light bulb that is dimmable.
answer: In short, No. That said, it depends on the LED light. Most dimmable LED's start to flicker when they get below 20% of full brightness. I have Switch Bulbs on a Maestro and they begin to flicker at about 15 to 20% of full brightness, it's dim but not to the level incandescent can get. I also have Phillips & Switch bulb (2 connected lamps) on a Diva dimmer and the Phillips flickers well before the Switch. Now I co have several Cree Recesses lights (Home Depot) on a Diva dimmers and they dim down right to candle light level. All the switches I use are designed for CFL & LED. The fact that the Cree recessed lights go all the way down to that barely on level I think has more to do with the lights LED electronics rather than the Maestro or Diva dimmer. I haven't used enough variety to be suitably knowledgeable in a definitive manner. Hope this helps.

question: Is there a difference between the 2 bags of densifier/sealer and how do I apply it?
answer: I'm still experimenting with this myself, but i believe there is indeed a difference between the two. the densifier is to be applied after you grind to about 600-800 grit clean it and apply the densifier. this is supposed to change the structure of the concrete by filling the microscopic pores in the concrete. You can see if you need it after the 800 grit grind because the marble chips are starting to "slick up" and the concrete around the chips is still dull. (Make sure you wipe up all the old grit before going to the next grit. I use a clean damp rag each time.) Follow the instruction included or go on-line, as to how you mix this stuff, how you apply it and how long you let it set. I'm pretty sure its caustic so follow safety procedures as they recommend. After the densifier, continue through the grits and when finished, the sealer goes on last to close the pores of the floor to make it more stain resistant. I have seen certain comments on line that indicates it can dull the finished gloss a little so try it before going whole hog on the floor.

question: How do you install the bulb? The bulb has 2 pins and the ceramic block in the lamp doesn't seem to match.
answer: Be sure the QL-1000 quartz light is unplugged before you try putting the quartz light in. The little ceramic block is the receptor, and it will give way from a little bit of pressure. In other words, one end of the quartz light gets pushed in (about 2 mmm), before the other end is maneuvered in. Don't try to slide the quartz light in like a fluorescent light. There won't be enough room for it to go in. The trick, is angling the light in, and pushing one side in before the other side starts to fit. I go through those little lights about every week (assuming I am doing a lot of shoots all day long, 12 to 16 hours a day), or once every month (assuming I am doing about three shoots a month, 8 to 12 hours per shoot). The real problem with the QL-1000 is not putting the light in, it's tolerating the whirr of the built-in fan.

question: Will this work with a night light that uses a photocell?

Just remember that these lamps draw so little current, that you could leave these in a fixture that stays on all day and night & still will use less electricity than an incandescent bulb burning only 8 to 10 hours a day. Good luck.

question: So my doorbell is out and I want to check the wires, how does this work, like which end do i touch to the wires, or does each end touch one wire?
answer: It might but probably not as as simple as it sounds its not a yes or no answer. There are other ways to determine if the door bell is bad or another component BUT one would have to physically look at your door bell itself to see how that door bell button is configured. Mainly because this tester is basically a light bulb with a clip and a probe attached to it. As such it needs a positive voltage on either the probe or the clip and a negative or return on the other. Were you to connect this to your door bell all you would be doing would be connecting it to 2 points on the same positive wire as the negative( which you have to have in order for the tester light to come on) is a straight wire that goes from the ringer back to the door bell transformer BUT it might be behind the door bell winger. A typical door bell has 2 wires that when the door bell is pressed make a physical connection and allow the low voltage ( 6 to 28volts) to pass thru the button and go to the bell- ringer- chime and that makes noise. These hand held testers like this are generally used around automobiles & such where the negative (return) is the car battery which is physically connected to the vehicle body and you can attach the clip to any clean metal surface. Door bell buttons usually outlast the other parts of the system... Transformer and chimes typically go bad first.

question: will it fit my Dewalt DW9 107 battery charger?
answer: The question is whether the battery-pack is the same as your DeWalt battery-pack (which fits your drill, and presumably your charger). If the 14.4v 1.5Ah agrees, and the shape and part-numbers look very similar, you're probably okay. In 2008 I got a pair of aftermarket battery packs to replace the original DeWalt DW9092 14.4v battery packs that worked with my DW 954-2 Drill and DW9107 Charger (14.4v 1.5Ah). They came in boxes from Batteryprice.com Labeled "For Dewalt DE9091, DBP-144 NiCad". Somewhere I saw a reference "DW9092 Discontinued." There were "Standard" and "High Capacity" packs in my user manual. Best advice: Contact the after-market seller, with your old DeWalt drill, battery-pack and charger ID-NUMBERS, and have them verify the replacement battery-pack is an exact replacement for your DeWalt original battery-pack.

question: Why does the thermostat continue to run the AC when set temperature has been reached? NOTE: I have "smart recovery" turned off.
answer: Is the compressor running or just the fan/coil unit after the temperature is reached? Does it cut off after a couple of minutes? If it just keeps running, it sounds like it might have been wired incorrectly, assuming the "Fan" switch isn't in the "On" position (if it is, switch it to the "Auto" position). If it just continues to run for a couple of minutes, I think the thermostat is likely programmed to do that as a (mildly misguided) effort at efficiency by taking advantage of the low refrigerant temperature that lingers a bit after the compressor has shut off. I actually don't have this model (and am not sure why Amazon thinks I do), and I am going from the behavior of the model TX5000Ua that I do have.

question: What is the spray width at various distances from the shower head, with and without the splash guard?
answer: Originally, High Sierra Showerheads were not equipped with the Splash Guard. It was added later after feedback from some customers indicated that some very small droplets that break away from the main part of the spray were bothersome. These wayward droplets don't contribute to the force of the spray because they are so few, but they can fall outside the tub depending on the height of the shower head. With the Splash Guard the effective spray is really not narrower than the without, but the Splash Guard works like a choke on a shotgun and pushes the wayward droplets back into the spray. For that reason, I usually recommend the Splash Guard for home use. The effective spray width of both models measures about 6 " at 1 ft from the shower head and increases to 18" at 5 to 6 ft.

question: which timer needs no neutral?
answer: I used this timer because it was possible to install it in a 3-way situation because there is a matching remote switch. If you're not doing a 3-way ANY timer you can find at Home Depot or Lowes will be fine. Both the timer(located with the LOAD connections) and the remote(which is located with the LINE connections) require a neutral wire. question: How thick can this be done at one pour?

question: What is the latest expiration date shown on the canisters? A date of 10/13/15 is far too soon. Is an expiration date of any use, anyway?
answer: I bought these about six months ago and the expiration date is 04/09/18. As for the usefulness, the expiration date is the point to which the manufacturer will stand behind the product. It doesn't suddenly stop working after that, you just run an increasing chance it will not work properly after that date. In reality it might work fine two years after the expiration date, but do you want to take the risk? They don't cost much, so I would just replace them.

question: How easy is it to remove this tape? I want to use it under a rug to keep the rug from slipping.

question: Please recommend a thermostat fo this heater. I'm confused about single pole v. double pole.
answer: SINGLE POLE thermostats have one wire that breaks only one side of the power supply line. The control knob will have a low temperature setting, but no "OFF" position. DOUBLE POLE thermostats have two wires and break both sides of the power supply line. The control knob will have an "OFF" position. I recommend douple pole.

question: i have 3/4 " copper. the port size on the rheem unit is 1/ 2". will this compromise the water pressure much?

The hot pressure is a bit lower then the cold .But like I said the right GPM shower head and adjusting the temp ,so you are not set at too low of a setting that the Rheem shuts off during use .It just took some fine tuning .The pressure can also be affected by hard water . Use a recommended filter ,or once a year it is simple enough to remove the unit and flush out the core in vinegar or a Lime-Away type product .And you won't lose that extra bit of pressure that the water filter can cause .Mine is well into its second year of use with no problems at all ,once I tuned it to my needs :)

question: Why is the light bulb flashing when it was installed in my night light?
answer: Responding to your question not only as a very satisfying customer and user, but also as an old retired electrical engineer [ MSEE '71, Caltech ], I can tell you the following based on my understanding/perception of the ELECTRONIC DESIGN OF THIS CLASS OF LED LIGHT BULBS : They must have built-in micro-electronic power-converters to allow the conversion of our 115 Vac household power to about 3 Vdc power that's right for turning on an LED .. If the night light holder has an 'electronic light-sensing AUTO on/of' switch function, it may not be in sync, or compatible, with this LED lamp and many others; and thus, FLASHING results. I HAVE ENCOUNTERED THIS PROBLEM, TOO. My solution: Knowing that these LED lamps will last a long time while burning very little juice, I SIMPLY USE A MECHANICALLY-SWITCHED LAMP HOLDER FOR THEM, AND LEAVE THEM 'ON' 24/7 . .. Then, I remain to be a happy camper.

question: is this wilton vice surface mounted or under bench face mounted
answer: Hello Scott. Woodworkers vices like this one are mounted under the bench with the top edge of the jaws flush with the top surface of the bench. If you have something that you want to lay flat on the bench and hold with the clamp, the outer (moving) jaw has a "dog" that slides up to protrude above the bench surface. To hold the other end of the piece, you would use bench dogs that slide down into holes in the bench top (typically 3/4" diameter). Here is an example of the bench dogs, and similar ones can be bought elsewhere, like Rockler's. http://www.amazon.com/Kreg-Tool-Company-KKS1070-Bench/dp/B006Q8TN4O/ref=sr_1_3?ie=UTF8&qid=1372190882&sr=8-3&keywords=bench+dog

question: Please compare this with the Klein Tools VDV226-011-SEN Ratcheting Modular Crimper/Stripper/Cutter - 31.25 compared to 65.35 today, 03 21 2014 ?
answer: The platinum tools crimper will work with ordinary RJ-45 connectors. It is also part of a connector system that eases the creation of perfect terminations. The EZ-45 connector has perforations that allow the conductors to pass through the connector body, inspected and pulled taught prior to crimping. The Platinum crimper has an extra blade that then snips the excess length off of the conductor at the completion of the crimp cycle. I believe it is feature that makes it tough to go back to other field terminations methods. It is a cost effective time saving process.

question: How wide of cloth should I lay on the carpet when I am spray painting the wall? I am scared that the paint particles get bounced onto the carpet.

question: I have installed standard water heaters before. Is this more difficult?
answer: I am no pro but I am a "handy" female and I installed one this weekend. Mounting was so easy it should not be a worry and The outside Tankless heater does not need venting so that was a big plus for me. There are Three things you must check you have before you start: #1 Must have 3/4 inch gas line (check for your model) for this model. I upgraded mine by replacing the T at the main pipe (Tankless needs the capacity so no cheating by using a reducer to size up from smaller capacity). #2 Must Get the Tankless Water Heater Service Valve Kit or you will not be able to service/clean it and save yourself heartache (it will break easier than standard HW heaters if not serviced regularly) I got mine at HD. #3 Needs 110 v electricity (I put in a light switch outside and put outside cover over it so we could turn it on/off as needed). One thing everyone should be aware of that can be a gotcha: There is a sensor which will not allow the unit start until all gas/water/electricity are hooked up and if you do try to start it before then (such as when trying to test the electricity to the thermostat like me), their is a sensor that will not allow it to start until everything is hooked up. The thermostat may not come on after doing this. It needed to be reset by turning the electricity to it on and off; I just used the GFI on the outlet on this electrical run to turn the electricity off and then back on to do a easy disconnection/reconnection of the electricity to thermostat which did the trick. The thermostat came back to life and it worked. Now my tenant is enjoying hot water. This guys installation videos were excellent and where I learned about the valves! http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LKhXoaRg6k4 Hope this helps. I will be getting mine inspected by the city as part of an existing permit for a remodel. Let you know if anything comes up after that, but it should not.

question: does this pump shut off when a certian pressure is reached? in other words does it opperate on demand? thanks
answer: It does NOT operate on demand. Plug it in and it runs. Remove the plug and it shuts off. As long as you have it in water the suction remains constant. Having said all that, I love this pump. My only problem is that it is sooo heavy. I use it mainly to empty my 150 gal fish tank prior to cleaning and to empty my grandchildrens' 15' swimming pool every Fall. I just attach a long hose to the pump and water my garden flowers until the pool is empty. Only once did it give me a problem and that was when I took the protective screen off the intake and it sucked up a large piece of gravel from the fish tank. Something broke inside. But my son went up to Lowe's for a little part and it was good as new. You must remember to prime it before use by putting some water in it. I would definitely buy another one if necessary but I wouldn't be surprised if it outlived me. I'm 70. I suppose that what you would use it for would determine how well it would work for you. For me it's perfect. Good luck.

question: the water just started coming out as a slow drip, after only a month of use. Should that happen?

question: I live in a windy area, and the outside vent cover (plastic) opens in heavy wind, which allows the internal baffle to flap (loudly)--Any solutions?
answer: I am familiar with two vent flappers. One is in the Panasonic unit, the other is a "clothes dryer" type at the exit through the wall or roof. Both types depend on gravity to close them. Be sure both flappers are installed correctly for the gravity assist. My guess is the primary problem is the "outside" vent flapper. Try another type of "dryer " vent. If that doesn't work try a baffle around the vent to disturb the air flow. When we get the strong Santa Ana winds here in Southern California, I can hear the wind slightly when standing under the unit even though the vent pipe run is about 12 feet from the unit to the outside vent. I do not get any "blowback" in air through the unit, nor does the flap in the unit "flap" open and closed with the strong winds. If your flappers are installed properly to take advantage of gravity, then a baffle around the outside vent to disturb the airflow may be your best bet.

question: Are the bulbs bright enough to replace 60w bulbs? Lower lumens I know, but noticeable? Any 'hum' like GE energy smart bulbs I am returning.
answer: Absolutely no hum noise. Regarding brightness, it's a bit of a trick question. As you can configure the color, using a very cold color has higher lumens, and would replace a 60W with warmer color (lower lumens). But at equal color, you would notice the difference. Precisely in my case, for a living room, it did not adequately replace 60W & 75W equivalent bulbs, I had to put two Hue bulbs in some cases instead of one CFL. But FYI one working trick is to replace in a living room most bulbs with Hue ones, and keep a few (like some ceiling lights) regular high-watt bulbs. At the end of the day, you don't need super bright light all the time, but usually only from time to time. So you turn on the regular bulbs only when you need really bright light in your room.

question: Can this item be mounted on a glass door? Industrial 2 way tape? HD velcro? Thanks!!
answer: The normal installation puts a magnet on the top corner of the doorway while the unit is mounted on the top corner of the door with the top of the unit lined-up with the magnet. To mount the unit on a glass may require the frame on the glass door be at least 3 inches wide. The STI 6400 unit is 5.37 inches X 5.37 inches while the mounting holes on the unit are halfway between the top and bottom and parallel with the top of the door. question: How do you set the date? When you press the record button as instructed it starts recording regardless of arrows. I cannot figure this out. Help!
answer: With the screen off, press the power button, then the options button (the gear). Use the arrow keys to navigate to the Date & Time option and press the power button. The new menu shows On, Off, and Set Date & Time. Use the arrow keys to navigate to the Set option and press the power button. When the next screen shows, the year should be highlighted. Press the record button once (don't hold it down) and then use the arrow keys to select the year. Pressing the record button again will move the highlighted selection to the next part of the date and you use the arrow keys again to select the date. Hitting the record button will continue cycling through the available date and time fields. Hope this helps! If not, feel free to ask more questions. :)

question: How long is the cord?
My heater is able to warm the water but not make it hot. Is there a safety shutoff that needs to be reset? Is that the thermal cut out?
answer: I own one and I love it! First thing to check is the temperature adjustment knob under the unit is turned fully clockwise. The temperature rise can vary widely based upon that and other things, such as... the incoming water temperature, the flow in GPM (consider the flow all fixtures whixh are being used at the same time if more than one are... the higher the flow rate, the lower the water temperate rise. Also, if yours is a 240VAC unit and your actual voltage is less like 220VAC it won't warm water as much as 240 does. If your faucets, etc. are too far from the heater... some heat can be lost in the run of pipe, especially if it is in a cold area. Note that what causes thermal shutdowns to occur is overtemp, this can happen if the flow is restricted quite a bit, but high enough to activate the heater, and when the incoming water temp is very high. Also never try to connect this type of heater to water the is already preheated. I have some AE9.5 units as well and I know they have the thermal shutdown, I think all Bosch units do.

question: What's the difference in the FC350B and the FR350B? I am researching as a Christmas present for my handyman husband's first pneumatic nailer?
answer: The C stands for "Clipped" and the R stands for "Round". That designates what type of nail can be used in the nailer. The clipped nails have heads that are shaped like a "D", whereas the round are shaped like an "O", logically. For the user, this means a few things. The clipped heads can be stacked with the shafts much closer, as the clipped side of the nail doesn't interfere with the shaft of the next nail. This means you can fit more nails in the nailer, and thus less reloading. The advantage of the round head nail is that the head is slightly larger, and thus less likely to be pulled through the board when the structure is put under stress. I researched this a bit, and most contractors (I'm a DIYer, like your husband) seemed to feel that they didn't notice a difference in the strength. I've never had an issue with it myself, and I've done remodel work in both my home and some commercial property my wife and I own. One last thing to consider is local building code. In some areas, code requires round head nails. This is mainly in the southeast coastal areas. The concern is hurricanes could stress structures to the point where the nail head will make a difference. Sorry for being long-winded. If you are interested in more information/opinions, just google "clipped vs round head framing nailer" and you will find all kinds of debates. Good luck, I'm sure he'll love it. I know I do!

question: to put this part on,do I take the tank off ?
answer: Yes... it is pretty easy though... You need to shut off the water valve that feeds the tank and unscrew from tank, flush to remove the water. I used a cup to scoop out the rest of the water then used a towel to get anything left. Unscrew the two screws in the bottom of the tank and lift the tank off. There is rubber gasket between the tank and the bowl- DO NOT THROW THIS OUT as this kit does not come with that gasket. Using the provided tool take off the large nut that holds the valve on. replace the valve and use the tool to tight. Put the other gasket in the hole and place the tank on the bowl. Fasten it with the screws and tighten. Replace the water intake. That's it... if things go well, about a half hour.

question: is the data logger unit water proof? Product specs. details are abysmal at Amazon.
answer: Here's what the user manual says: The data logger is protected against moisture to IP67 standard when the plastic cap and seal are fitted. ... What is IP67? IP67 is an internationally recognized standard describing the requirements for dust tight and waterproof systems and is based on the test specified in EN60947-5-1. An IP rating of IP67 is capable of being submerged in water to a depth of one metre for a duration not exceeding 30 minutes. How is an IP67 rating achieved? On the EL-USB-1, IP67 is achieved via an O-ring that is fitted between the translucent cap and the data logger body

question: Can this unit be used as a Primary Unit? We are in a very dry state and need a sump pump only occasionally.
answer: If you are in a dry state and need an occasional pump I would use a traditional sump pump run on electricity. The purpose of the water run liberty pumps is to back up a traditional sump pump if the electricity is out due to a storm. They are more expensive than an electric sump pump and I do not know what kind of useful life you will get out of one if it is used as a primary pump. To answer your question, yes it can be. But if it were me I would use the electric as my primary and if you need a back up then use the Liberty.

question: All the talk about Dual action and orbital, What is really best? Why is a orbital so different (other than speed control) than the old buffer/polisher
answer: Depends really on what your ultimate goal is for what you are doing. Rotarys require some skill to master if you do not know what you are doing you can cause some serious damage even with a foam pad and polish. However, rotaries also have the ability to work much faster and remove more severe defects from the surface. You can get a flawless finish with a rotary with the correct pad and polish. Now, if you are new to polishing and sick of doing things by hand a DA polisher is the tool for you. If you get somthing like a porter cable or meguiars it is a non forced rotation. What this means is when too much pressure is applied the pad will stop rotating and just vibrate on the surface. DA's are great for getting flawless finishes on decent paint . They excel at removing swirls and light oxidation with NO buffer marks. If you need speed the rotary is the way to go. I have both the porter cable and makita. I prefer the rotary, but if you are just a hobbyist i recommend a DA polisher. They are safer and you will get a better finish if your skill level is low.

question: can i use it for knowing the % of humidity in milled corn, soybeans seed for animalfood?
answer: Not "humidity," but moisture content of grain & seed kernels. I'm actually using it for the moisture content of coffee-beans at differing stages of processing/drying, up to green coffee for roasting. Coffee beans are similar in size to Soy-beans, so I use that setting. There are settings for rice, wheat,.... I've compared the readouts to known samples and they're close enough for my purposes. It'll give both temperature and percent humidity readings of bagged seeds, and seems more accurate if the bags are stacked, so that the grain is "compressed." Read the instruction guide. I believe it takes an indirect measurement of the grain by measuring electrical resistance/conductivity of the grain sample. Kind of like a soil-meter.

question: does the covering have to be removed for use of the machine? or does it have separate openings for the setting knobs as well as the cover of the machine?

For the washer, since the door is on top, it holds the cover open without any problem. For the dryer, I use the heavy detergent bottle to sit it on top holding the cover open. question: I am powering this off a motion sensor and it has a lot of buzzing/clicking when on. I remove the motion sensor, it works fine. What am i doing wrong?
answer: Andy - I connected my contactor to a Variac and measured the coil current. I measured the following: Pull-in current 145mA to 155mA. Sustaining current 60mA. Drop out current about 30 mA. The solenoid buzzed really badly if the available current was LESS than 145 mA at pull-in, which leads me to believe that your problem is the output driver on the motion sensor can't provide enough current to pull the contactor in. You can measure the sensor output current to the contactor coil by CAREFULLY connecting a multimeter, set to the 10 amps AC scale, in series with your coil drive circuit, and monitor the amount of current it's putting out while the contactor buzzes. Be careful, 120 volts. If your driver can't provide the current to drive the contactor, one way around this would be to use a second, smaller relay to pull in the bigger contactor. Typical "ice-cube" 120v coil relays just require ~ 10-20 mA to pull in. Then this small relay's contacts could activate the coil of the larger contactor. If your motion sensor is providing the proper current then the problem may be related to noise, but I'd check your driver circuit's current capability first. Greg Walz greenlite350@aol.com

question: Is this tool what I would use to close silver rings on a charm bracelet?
answer: Soldering is a confusing topic for people who are new jewelry making. There are two totally different ways to solder that use different types of soldering equipment, but few people ever specify which method they're talking about. Solder is a metal alloy which you melt to coat or connect metal pieces - if it helps, think of solder as hot metal glue. The act of soldering is melting and applying solder. The two aforementioned methods of soldering are soldering with a torch and soldering with a soldering iron.Torch soldering is also known as "hard soldering," "brazing," or "silver soldering" even though brass, copper, gold, and other metals can be soldered with a torch. There are multiple grades of hard solder - soft, medium, and hard - which melt at different temperatures. You can solder base metals, like pewter, and plated metals with a soldering iron, which is known as soft soldering. Soft solder has a relatively low melting point. Never use a soldering iron to work on precious metals because you will ruin the jewelry. Silver and gold jewelry must be torch soldered. Successful soldering involves heating the metal pieces - not just melting the solder - meaning that if a piece of jewelry is large or thick, chances are it was torch soldered. Soldering irons are not all the same. There are a wide variety of irons available, but the majority are not designed for making jewelry. The most important features to look for are wattage and the type of tip. Look for a sixty-watt chisel-tip soldering iron (you can also buy soldering iron tips separately). Soldering irons with pointy tips are designed for small electronics like circuit boards and aren't appropriate for working with jewelry, unless you replace the tip. Soldering irons with fewer than sixty watts may not heat up sufficiently. Use lead-free solid-core solder and avoid solder with acid or rosin cores. Solder needs flux, which is sometimes included with solder, to melt and flow.

question: where is the battery located my lighthouse has an on off switch on the solar stake should it be on all the time
answer: I had THREE (3) lighthouses; not because I wanted or needed three, but because none of these worked and their very excellent, most responsive customer service rep -in Calif., I think- kept replacing the inoperative product -the WHOLE lighthouse! Frankly I do not recall any battery being associated with the lighthouse itself or in the on/off stake. The fixture was completely solar is my best recollection. I could be wrong. I believe instructions called for the on/off to be in the "on" position while the solar plate was exposed to the sun over a day or so to collect and store energy for nighttime illumination. But not one of the lighthouses worked. I believe the wiring was too delicate to withstand the trip from China. What I did was to purchase a $10 solar spotlight from Walmart which I "jimmyrigged" into the lighthouse tower replacing the inoperative parts. This approached worked beautifully and was further enhanced by the purchase of another Walmart spotlight which I positioned to illuminate the whole lighthouse, illuminated tower included. Really quite beautiful in our backyard!

question: Is it dimmable?
answer: if the LED driver you have purchased is not marked specifically for Dimmable use it is not dimmable, there are a number of factors within the Driver design that specify dimming capabilities, and manufacturers who manufacture a dimmable supply won't quickly forget to leave those details out because a dimmable supply usually cost a little more than a standard supply, you can dim the secondary side with the proper low voltage dimmer, however in some cases dimming on the secondary side can cause eratic function of the led array and in some cases cause the led to not function at all, also if you have purchased a driver and sim it on the secondary side you may void you warranty on the led array, driver or both. i am a Journeyman electrician and have several years of working with led's and thier equipment and accessories.

question: My tool has froze up. Never spilled on it, had about a year now, occasional use. I tried using WD40 and q-tips to clean it, no success...any insight?
answer: You need to get a Penetrating oil/fluid (which WD-40 is NOT) and soak the knife in it for a couple of hours. Or, since the tool is stainless you can also try soaking it in warm, soapy water for a while. Once you get the tool opened up, THEN souse 'er down good with the WD-40. It sounds to me like someone's maybe peeled a sugary fruit with the knife blade, and let that juice run down in all the crevices and then put the tool up without cleaning it good first. You'll get it squared away, no doubt. Good luck.

question: can i use one remote for two different fans? my dog also chewed my remote and i have two of the same fans in one room.
answer: It's not a good idea, but technically yes. The remotes and the receivers have dip switches on them. As long as the settings on both are the same, the remote will control the fan. Therefore, if you have two fans with two receivers that both have the same settings as a single remote, it would operate both of them. However, I wouldn't assume it will control them in unison, especially if both fans are not perfectly within line of sight of each other. For that reason I would recommend a second remote (you can use the same type; it would just be controlled with a different setting). Regardless of that, will it work? Yes.

question: With the CL2000 in the DC Amp mode, and the leads not connected to anything, the meter fluctuates between 01.59A and 01.66A. Why?
answer: Steve, I just discovered the adjustment pot for zeroing (or at least get it close to spec) the DC clamp current. Turn the meter over, then open and remove the battery cover. On the back you will find two holes to the left of the center chassis screw. The hole closest to that center chassis screw locates the adjustment pot for the DC clamp current mode. Turn the pot clockwise to decrease the value towards negative, counter-clockwise to increase the value towards positive. Use a miniature Phillips #1 (3mm shaft) screwdriver. See the photo I uploaded.

question: does this work for detecting dog urine?
answer: Our light is going to work as well if not better than any other light on the market for detecting dog urine. The glasses are geared more towards cat owners since cats spray on areas other than the carpets which can be hard to spot but depending on the type of carpet and color dog owners can benefit from using them as well. A common theme you will notice as you look through the reviews of all the UV lights is most of the complaints are from dog owners. UV works on 'dry' urine and the combination of phosphor, proteins, salt and blood in the urine. Kidney function and water intake will also influence how well the urine will show. For these reasons cat urine usually shows better than dog urine with the UV. Please let us know if you have any additional questions and these type of questions are also answered in the "Quick Start Guide" that is emailed to you when your item ships along with a hard copy that is included with your kit.

question: To use this in an audio amplifier circuit that requires +/- 50V, do I need two of these for the two polarities?
answer: I have not tried feeding one into the other, mine are in parallel with a common output feed, but feeding it into series might work. If I did try the series, I would set them up separately, and make the load on each the same, then apply them into series. The thing you will need to be very careful of on an amplifier is what kind of Amperage are you pulling on the amp? In my experience with them, these can handle up to 4-5 amps without an issue, but over that, you may find that you would be happier with a bigger unit. Also, make sure that you have a meter handy, as there is no other way to know the output in the board itself. If you decide to use these, and start making adjustments to the pod, it is an extremely fine adjustment ratio, you may turn 2 or 3 revolutions to get 1 or 2 volts, so if you start adjusting, and don't see the meter moving much, keep turning, it will eventually move.

question: how many amps does this pump draw?

question: How close to the ceiling can this be hung? I don't want to use the 2' of chain it comes with...is that possible?
answer: You can hang it as close as you want - I removed a bunch of links from the chain with pliers, and have it hanging about 5 or 6 inches from the ceiling. But you could even leave just a couple chain links and have it almost right up against the ceiling. For aesthetics, you can also trim down the power cord so that there's not a lot of slack hanging over the chandelier. Unfortunately there's not a lot of space in the dome for all the extra cord, so if you're hanging close the ceiling, you will most likely have to trim the cord. The downside to cutting the cord is that if you ever want to hang the chandelier lower, you might not have enough cord length remaining, so just keep that in mind.

question: If there is a warranty issue with this welder how would I go about getting service?
answer: I have had my machine for about 5 months. Right out of the box I had an issue with the high frequency start. I contacted AHP and was helped. I had to do my own repairs with the Tech on the phone. Better than shipping it back to California. Then I had an issue with the Machine leaking argon gas. I contacted AHP again and was semi helped. We went through a procedure to see what was leaking. Couldn't hear the leak but it was substantial, approx 7 cubic feet per hour. I even sent a video to AHP and have never heard back from them. Left many messages via phone and emails past 3 months. NOTHING!!!!! I had to break down and take it in to a local repair facility to have it checked out on my own dime. Now it is fixed. I shouldn't have to do that, it is and was under warranty, Pretty bad customer service.

question: Can more than one remote control the same switch? IE, one remote to control light-A and a second remote to control light-A with light-B.

So I would expect that you can program one Pico controller to control switch A, and a second Pico controller to control switch A and switch B. question: What are the maximun watts for this cord?
answer: Using the tables I have included to answer this question...with a 3.2 voltage drop threshold this 12 gauge 50 foot cable should handle 2400 watts. 120 Volt Extension Cord Table (less than 3.2 voltage drop) 10 amps === 16 gauge @ 25 feet --- 14 gauge @ 50 feet --- 12 gauge @ 100 feet --- 10 gauge @ 150 feet** 15 amps === 14 gauge @ 25 feet --- 12 gauge @ 50 feet --- 10 gauge @ 100 feet --- 8 gauge @ 150 feet** 20 amps === 12 gauge @ 25 feet --- 12 gauge @ 50 feet --- 10 gauge @ 100 feet* --- 6 gauge @ 150 feet** * Exception 4.8 voltage drop for 20 amp 100 foot cable. ** You would most likely have to hand build these longer cables. Watts Table 10 amps @ 120 volts = 1200 watts 15 amps @ 120 volts = 1800 watts 20 amps @ 120 volts = 2400 watts

question: Does anyone know if I could put L14-20 on one end of cable and L14-30 on the other end to connect to a distribution box with the L14-30 end?
answer: I'm no home electrician, but as an auto electrical tech I'm pretty good with wiring. So if I understand this correctly the L14-30 on the cable is going into the L14-30 on the box, and you want the L14-20 on the other end of the cable will be going into a gen or other power unit, correct? This would work as far as the connecting everything.... meaning the ends will all fit together. The problem is Amps. The L14-30's are rated at 2X30 amp lines with 1 shared ground and 1 shared common, where the L14-20 is only rated at 2X20 amp power lines with common and ground. I don't know that this would be to code first off so I have to add the disclaimer "check with a licensed electrician". As far as "in theory", yes, this would work as far as getting power from point A to B. But your box is rated at 30 amps with a full load(all breakers on), your L14-20 is only 20 amps. So while in an emergency you could provide power to the box, you would never have enough amperage to turn all the breakers on at once without risking an overload. I'd also like to add, That you will need to know how your box is wired to "safely turn breakers on without overloading". Since you have 2 poles feeding the breakers, you will only have 20 amps available PER POLE or per wire. Its not like some think 2X20 means I can turn 40 amp worth of breakers on, you will be limited to 20 amps per wire or you could/will blow the safety (if equipped) on the gen. You can not just assume the left side is one (pole) or wire and the right side the other. Sometimes they are and sometimes they are not. Also keeping in mind that double breakers pull from both sides or wires at once. Hope this helps and feel free to contact me or ask another question. If I can help I will.

question: Did anyone do a calculation to measure the electicity cost to run these per month?
answer: The device is rated at .8 of a watt. In the worst case, if it runs in a room that stays completely dark 24 hours a day (e.g., never shuts off), for 30.25 days a month it will consume about 6.3 cents of electric power per month, assuming that you pay about 11 cents per kilowatt hour including taxes (as I do). The calculation is .8 watts * 24 hours * 30.25 days / 1000 watts (kilowatt) * .11 (the cost of a kilowatt hour). Your actual cost will probably be something less, because light in the room will shut the light off for some part of the day, and some light in the room will cause the device to dim and thereby also use less power than the .8 watt that it is rated at.

question: how do you remove the water restrictor
answer: Found this explanation on another website. I have not tried it, but offered for what it is worth: Take out the screen and black gasket out from the stem. You'll see a green plastic device and a small black rubber ring; they appear to be integrated into the base of the shower head and can't be removed. So what I did is use a common nail (I had some galvanized 10D 3 inch nails in the garage) and, using a hammer, gently punched a hole right into the center of the green plastic piece. Then, using a pair of tweezers, I was able to completely remove all of the green plastic pieces. Be careful that the pieces don't enter into the shower head itself. Put the screen back in place (this prevents particles in your water from entering and clogging the shower head) and screw the shower head back on.

question: What size rough-in valve does this fit?
answer: Delta R2707 (Flexible Roman Tub Rough). The same rough-in valve set is used for all roman tub trims EXCEPT those with a separate hand sprayer which needs Delta Faucet R4707 (Flexible Roman Tub with Hand shower Rough). In general for delta products any model number that starts with BT or T means "trim only", any model number which begins with R is the rough in kit. Delta does sell the trim + valve as a combo for some models. It will be the same model number but WITHOUT the "BT" or "T" prefix. Plumbing supply houses tend to carry the rough-in + trim as separate items and the big box stores tend to carry the "combo".

question: would this be an appropriate filter for spraying paint in a room, or cleaning a floor with an acid wash?
answer: Hi Aaron. This would NOT be very appropriate for that. This filter just stops particulates - basically dust, dirt, maybe pollen, any particle that floats in the air. The filter you want to use for painting and cleaning is termed with "organic vapor". Search for the product named "3M 6001 Organic Vapor Cartridge". That's the type of filter to use for most types of chemical vapors. (Always be sure to read the fine print though.) But that will work for typical cleaning and painting. I personally use that one, and it works really well. (Make sure when you're done to store the organic vapor ones in an air-tight ziploc bag to prolong their life.)

question: I have a nightclub that just opened up about 2 months ago that is approximately 300 feet from my home. Will it pick up the bass heard in my home?
answer: There are two weighting curves, A and C. A weighting tends to disregard the bass, but is the legal standard, i.e. laws specifying the threshold for legal action are usually written for A weighting. In practice I have found that some meters respond more to low frequencies than others, both meters using C weighting. Strictly speaking this shouldn't happen, but weighting standards may allow quite a few decibels of "slop" around the specified weighting curve at high and low frequency extremes.

question: what does merv number mean?
answer: The MERV number is a rating system. Minimum efficiency report value (MERV). Basically, the higher the MERV rating the greater percentage of particles captured. MERV 11 as this filter is, is for Superior Residential applications, meaning it's the higher end of the residential markets. The next bump up is MERV 13 which is typically used in a hospital type setting.

question: I would like to use this to operate four sets of outdoor spotlights so there is about 300 feet total. Does this timer work for that length of wire?
answer: In my opinion - and it's only an opinion, as I'm not a licensed electrician - is that is more dependent on the circuit that operates the spotlights. As long as the circuit can manage the power going to those floods, then this switch is simply there to time the on/off aspect. There may actually be a limit to the amount of electricity you can send through the switch, but I doubt that a normal application would exceed that limit. Personally, I use this to operate a bathroom fan that acts as our fresh air return system for a small (1,200 sq.ft.) home. After tightening up the house with recent energy upgrades, and moving to sealed combustion for furnace and water heater, I needed a way to regularly cycle the air in the house. This switch works like a charm with up to 50 on/off points programmable for a single day, and the option to have a full 7-day schedule.

question: can I operate the lock without nexia

So you can either use the Nexia hub and subscribe to their service, or you can use another home automation hub that support the Schlage touchpad lock. It is a great lock, good luck.

question: What is the assembled dimensions of the stand w/o the arms extended? I am looking for the dimensions between the feet when open. Thanks!
answer: The top frame of the stand is 8-3/4" deep and 44 "wide. At the floor the outside dimensions are 54-3/8" wide by 24-3/4 deep. Since the legs slope outward and are about 1-1/4" square you could get the inside dimension by subtracting 2-1/2". If you need to put something under the stand you must allow for the slope of the legs. The arms extend about 36" each side. The two support beams for the saw or other tool are 20" long and extend about 4'' over the front top 44" beam and 7" behind the rear top beam. I use a DeWalt 12 miter saw on mine and have found the stand to be strong and stable.

question: Can you use latex paint with this sprayer
answer: You can usually dilute latex paint up to 10%, but the risk of sagging increases with the percentage. However, it's best to use a larger nozzle with a product called Floetrol and minimize the water. It is not a replacement for water. It helps the paint flow better and allows you to use less water. How much? Depends on a lot of things but paint temperature and nozzle size are to key factors. For this gravity-fed sprayer, you really should do it at room temperature, with a 1.7 - 2.5-mm nozzle. Add the Floetrol as directed (8-16 oz per gallon). You'll need a larger screen because latex is thick and will clog up regular ones. Then spray from about 6-8 inches away. These are just starting points; you'll need to find out what works best for you.

question: If I install a Kwikset SmartCode Z-Wave Deadbolt, can I use this controller with it? Will I have the ability to control who and when can unlock my door? Can I configure the system to send me a text message when the door is unlocked by a specific person?
answer: Others have mentioned that proximity between the Zee and your lock is a factor. This is partially correct, because a Z-Wave network is a "mesh" network, in that other devices have the ability to act as repeaters. You could say that the more Z-Wave components you have, the better all of it should work (in theory). In my house, I have two other Z-Wave components in between my Zee and my door lock (mine is a Yale). I've never had a connectivity issue. I DO NOT have the ability to program the door lock (entry codes, etc) through the interface of the HomeSeer API. Nope. I do this on the lock itself. We have four codes set up on ours. You asked about text messages when the door is unlocked by a specific person (code). YES, this is possible via the Zee's HS3 software, in a way. What is actually happening is the Zee sends an email, not a text message. However, most wireless providers have a function where an email can be sent as a text message. This is how I accomplish the notification that my wife and I both receive via SMS whenever our teenager uses his code to unlock the door. Here is an example of the above on AT&T's network: http://www.att.com/esupport/article.jsp?sid=KB63037&cv=820#fbid=_WFfaYxxr4L

question: Does this X10 switch work with LED bulbs. I have some old X10 switches but they do not work with LED bulbs. Wanted to know if this one will work.

question: Can this unit also be used for tiles? (Floor square/alignment)
answer: The short answer to this is, no. Projecting down from a truly vertical position would work in theory, but very difficult to do in practice. If the cross is not projected perfectly plumb to the floor, the cross beams won't be square. There are certainly ways to do it with this device by manually transferring points and snapping chalk lines, but you can do the same with a tape measure and chalk line. What you need is a laser that is designed for projecting a right angle on a floor. An example would be a GTL 3.

question: does anybody know what the main differences are between this jig and the "General Tools 860 dovetailer EZ Pro dovetail Jig" (cheaper one)?

question: When punching a small hole, does this tool leave any impression on the metal or mar it in any way? And how close can you punch the hole to the edge?
answer: It does not leave a mark or impression on the metal. It is best to mark your item with a fine point sharpie pen as to where you want to punch the metal--this will also help you center the punch with the mark. Look at the size of your punch and do a "run through" so to speak by lining up the dot to be punch and lowering the punch to see if you need to adjust where you want to center the punch. You never want to get too close to the edge as you don't want to have the hole edge to break easily. Test on some scrap metal if you are having some difficulties..it will give you a better perspective as to how close to the edge you can be. Hope this helps!

question: Why does it say "not for use with digital ballasts"? I want to use them on fluorescent lights, but I may change to led lights later. Is it OK for both
answer: Here is an answer from the mfg. CAUTION: Most Apollo timers are not for use with digital or electronic ballasts due to the high in-rush current of the ballast. The in-rush current can be from 10 to 40 times the rated amperage for the product and this burns the contacts inside of the timer making it inoperable. We recommend the use of the Apollo 4 120 Volt ballast timer or Apollo 5 240 Volt ballast timer with digital and electronic ballasts.

question: Does this work well with regular grill propane tanks? I saw in the comments that the flow regulators dampen the power of this torch. Is this true?
answer: I have been using the standard 20 lb propane tanks from walmart or any other place that has standard tanks. I have never had an issue with it tripping the "safety shut-off" that others have mentioned. I also have the "squeeze valve" that lowers the flame automatically to a pilot light level, and only goes on full when you squeeze. This will lesson the chance of tripping the safety shutoff because the gas increases more slowly as you squeeze. It is also drastically safer, as the gas will lower to pilot level if you drop the torch. Overall, if I squeeze fully the flame would set anything that is within 2-3 feet of the end ablaze. It produces a relatively loud roar that sounds like a jet engine. I cannot imagine wanting a much larger flame for home or small business purposes, so I definitely would say there are no visible limitations from the regulator on the tank.
